urn:contentItem:572F-1TN1-JD34-V2KH-00000-00A town like Wallace2012-11-17T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisTRAVELLERPg. 10A town like WallaceDESTINATION USElspeth Callender . The writer was a guest of Idaho Tourism.

Elspeth Callender sips a huckleberry shake and joins the Idaho townsfolk celebrating a tiny haven of eccentricity. Wallace, Idaho, is the centre of the universe. Until someone can scientifically disprove it, the 784 residents will continue to annually celebrate the fact around the manhole at the main intersection of town. "We're all odd ducks here," the Prime Minister tells me on my first evening in town.

"If we were normal, we'd be somewhere else."It's September and mild enough to dine on the footpath near the smokehouse's southern-style barbecue. The forested valley walls rise steeply around us and, after a long slow dusk, downtown Wallace begins to glitter and glow.Prime Minister Rick Shaffer is a tall, energetic blond in his mid-50s. We are joined by a wan young man fresh from the neighbouring state of Washington and a messy divorce who is obsessed with yoghurt-covered pretzels - another odd duck. Over a pulled-pork dish, Philadelphia-born Shaffer tells us everything he knows about this town he's called home for 20 years. In 1884, a Colonel Wallace, who wasn't actually a colonel, staked his claim and built a cabin in the swampy cedar forest and called it Placer Centre. His wife became the first postmistress in a town of 14, soon renamed Wallace. Coeur d'Alene was on its way to becoming the world's richest silver district. Before long the town of Wallace had a saloon, school, narrow-gauge railroad, plank footpaths, banditry, shoot-outs, bordellos and roving card sharps such Wyatt Earp.In 1890 a fire started in the flue of the Central Hotel and the whole business district - all wooden buildings - and pretty much the rest of town burnt down.Rebuilding was consciously done in brick and in 1910, when a huge forest fire swept through this narrow valley, only a third of the town was lost. Shaffer cites Lana Turner's birth in the local hospital in 1921, then jumps forward more than half a century to the building of the country's longest highway stretching 5000 kilometres, from Boston to Seattle. I wonder why he thinks we want to hear about some old road, then realise he's leading up to Wallace's second significant act of resistance, and one that has forged the town's collective consciousness.Wallace fought construction of the Interstate 90 through its centre by placing the entire downtown on the National Register of Historic Places. After holding up completion of the I-90 for 17 years a compromise was finally reached, but in the meantime Wallace got on a roll. Now virtually the whole town is on that register and any new shop-front business must comply with a strict set of aesthetic rules. "There will never be a Starbucks or a McDonald's here," Shaffer says, waving to some locals chugging down the main street on quad bikes, which the council allows and even advertises on its list of 89-plus things to do here (in winter it's snowmobiles). I'm beginning to notice that Wallace makes delicious mincemeat of the numerous stereotypes we hold about modern America. There are no police here, just a county sheriff. This town is so darned sweet, even the port-a-loos are branded Honey Bucket. "It's so weird," the man from Washington says. "It's like everyone who lives here has found home." He looks like he can't wait for that to happen to him, too, as we get up to leave.The following morning I've got time before meeting Shaffer for a walking tour of town and stop into Angie's Hub at Vintage Games. While Angie makes me a huckleberry shake, I ask if she was born here. "Nope," she tells me, looking happy, "I actively went in search of 'small town America' and just kept coming back to Wallace."Shaffer meets me at the universe's midpoint and we go from there. Sitting in the town's spaceship, I ask how he became PM and he tells me it began as a joke to a tour group back in 1993. Introducing himself as the US's only prime minister got such a good response he just kept using it. Twelve years later the council made it official and awarded him the city charter. He grins at me across the capsule: "In Wallace, anyone can be anything."FAST FACTSGetting there United Airlines flies direct from Sydney to San Francisco with connections to Spokane, Washington. Hire a car from the airport to drive the final 126 kilometres on the I-90 East.Staying there Stardust Motel is on the cheap and cheerful end from $US60 ($57.70) a night, 410 Pine Street, +1 208 752 1213, stardustmotelidaho.com. Alternatively, Beale House B&B is a charming historic home that isn't into children, from $US170/night, 107 Cedar Street, +1 208 752 7151, wallace-id.com /bealehouse.html.Touring there Rick Shaffer leads walking tours, driving tours, biking, hiking, ziplining and will even collect you from the airport. Price to be negotiated on booking, +1 800 643 2386, rshaffer@cebridge.net.While thereOasis Bordello Museum is a now-disused brothel frozen in time, 605 Cedar Street, +1 208 753 0801, $US5.Hire a bike and cycle the Idaho-Montana back-country Route of the Hiawatha. See ridethehiawatha.com.Cheer the hero, boo the villain and throw popcorn at a Sixth Street Theatre melodrama, 212 Sixth Street. See sixthstreetmelodrama.com.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Strategy call on TB epidemic</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>MIRANDA KORZY</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">AUSTRALIANS should heed the fierce tuberculosis epidemic among its neighbours and implement a national strategy to fight the disease at home, specialists warned yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">World Health Organisation (WHO) global TB program director Dr Arata Kochi said Australia was surrounded by TB hot zones, which needed aid to implement the WHO's DOTS strategy -Directly Observed Treatment Short Course.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Under this, health workers directly observed patients swallowing each dose of medicine and monitored their progress.</p><p>"As we approach the turn of the century, unless DOTS is used more widely and quickly, TB will continue to spread like a forest fire throughout the developing countries of the Asia-Pacific region, increasingly in multi-drug resistant forms for which no ready cure is available," Dr Kochi said in Sydney.</p><p> "I am very worried about the consequences for Australia, as well as other Asia-Pacific countries, if we delay in controlling TB in this region."</p><p> Dr Kochi's call coincided with the Federal Government's announcement that the Australian Aid program would increase its contribution to the WHO global tuberculosis program from $515,000 to $550,000 this financial year.</p><p> The size of the donation had been dictated by the "constrained budgetary environment", according to parliamentary secretary to Foreign Affairs Minister Andrew Thomson.</p><p> He said the program was the most significant operation fighting tuberculosis on a global level and the Australian Government had provided $1.16 million to it since 1994-95.</p><p> However, the chair of the TB group at the Thoracic Society of Australia and New Zealand, Professor Paul Seale, said Australia did not uniformly apply the DOTS strategy and called for a national approach.</p><p> "I would dearly love to have a national policy," Prof Seale said.</p><p> "We're (the thoracic society) developing a national policy its just a matter of how it gets implemented." Prof Seale said that in NSW treatment was supervised but standards varied in other States.</p><p> In Victoria, funding cuts meant supervision was not necessarily carried out and isolation in the Northern Territory made it difficult to implement.</p><p> Supervised treatment was important to ensure patients took a full course of drugs, he said.</p><p> The Asia-Pacific region gains six million new TB cases each year and three million people around the world die from it.</p><p> Australia had about 1000 new cases a year. Aborigines suffered the most TB, with 10.6 cases per 100,000 people, compared with 5.73 cases per 100,000 in the rest of the community, Prof Seale said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4NBY-TNY0-TX52-K1VP-00000-00Attack early to beat bushfires2007-03-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 17Attack early to beat bushfires

WHILE Victoria's Emergency Services Commissioner Bruce Esplin pontificates that summer's hyper fires are here to stay because of global warming, it is obvious he believes the problem can be solved by throwing buckets of taxes at fire suppression methods.

Mr Esplin has lost sight of the 40-year period between 1944 and 1984 when, with the aid of fuel reduction burning, timber industry burning and grazier blazes, bushfires were attended to within hours and lasted not much longer.

Whether the year is 2003, 2005, 2006 or 2007, our experience here in rural Australia is that the environmental gurus of East Melbourne have little understanding of fire.

Given fuel, wind and low humidity it only needs an ignition source to set a fire burning. That is the time to attack it rather than waiting for an increase in the fire size and an opportunity for a ''Section 44'' as it is called in NSW.

We don't want the Federal Government picking up the cost of fighting a hyper fire when it could have been quickly extinguished by good old fashioned basic forestry.

John Cribbes, Sale

Woodchipping

dries up key dam

EVERY year (to this very day) clearfelling of Melbourne's main water catchment goes on.

About 150ha of the Thomson Reservoir's highest rainfall catchment area is clearfelled, with 80 per cent going to woodchips.

Every year the public loses 20,000 megalitres of water (the size of a full Maroondah Dam) because of the extra water used by new eucalyptus trees in the coups. This means as we go further into drought our chances of getting any sustainable level of water back in the Thomson is close to zero.

The last two reports on the clearfelling of our main water catchment at the Thomson Reservoir have recommended stopping the practice now, as we are losing massive amounts of water.

I fully support value-added timber organisations but the woodchip industry has had a stranglehold over our Thomson water catchment for too long.

Is it water or woodchips for Victoria?

Robert Stephen,

Monbulk

Logging increases

risk of fires

FEDERAL Liberal MP Stewart McArthur, in attempting to defend the logging industry (WT, January 31), has blamed farmers for starting a fire that wiped out the US timber town of Peshtigo in 1871.

The fire, in fact, resulted from the burning of logging slash that had gone on for months in the surrounding logged forests, causing a pall of smoke to hang over the town.

Mr McArthur correctly states that the resulting firestorm was the result of extreme weather conditions, something that we will experience a lot of if we don't reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

Mr McArthur attempts to explain the devastation of Peshtigo by saying the town was ''effectively fuel for fire'', being made from timber, with sawdust strewn streets, much like a forest logging coup, with its piles of drying logs and dry logging slash.

Coup burns are carried out after logging has finished, risking damage to the surrounding forest (especially rainforest) and possibly a major fire.

After an area has been logged, the previously green moisture-retentive and structurally diverse forest is replaced by a uniformly structured ''plantation'' of small diameter trees, providing ideal fuel for a forest fire, as now demonstrated in East Gippsland.

The fast-growing young trees, as well as using up vast quantities of water, also shed bark and leaves at a faster rate than an unlogged mature forest, providing further fuel.

Stephen Chenery,

Otway Conservation

Council Inc.

Apollo Bay

Elspeth Callender sips a huckleberry shake and joins the Idaho townsfolk celebrating a tiny haven of eccentricity.

Wallace, Idaho, is the centre of the universe. Until someone can scientifically disprove it, the 784 residents will continue to annually celebrate the fact around the manhole at the main intersection of town. "We're all odd ducks here," the Prime Minister tells me on my first evening in town. "If we were normal, we'd be somewhere else."

It's September and mild enough to dine on the footpath near the smokehouse's southern-style barbecue. The forested valley walls rise steeply around us and, after a long slow dusk, downtown Wallace begins to glitter and glow.

Prime Minister Rick Shaffer is a tall, energetic blond in his mid-50s. We are joined by a wan young man fresh from the neighbouring state of Washington and a messy divorce who is obsessed with yoghurt-covered pretzels - another odd duck. Over a pulled-pork dish, Philadelphia-born Shaffer tells us everything he knows about this town he's called home for 20 years. In 1884, a Colonel Wallace, who wasn't actually a colonel, staked his claim and built a cabin in the swampy cedar forest and called it Placer Centre. His wife became the first postmistress in a town of 14, soon renamed Wallace. Coeur d'Alene was on its way to becoming the world's richest silver district. Before long the town of Wallace had a saloon, school, narrow-gauge railroad, plank footpaths, banditry, shoot-outs, bordellos and roving card sharps such Wyatt Earp.

In 1890 a fire started in the flue of the Central Hotel and the whole business district - all wooden buildings - and pretty much the rest of town burnt down.

Rebuilding was consciously done in brick and in 1910, when a huge forest fire swept through this narrow valley, only a third of the town was lost. Shaffer cites Lana Turner's birth in the local hospital in 1921, then jumps forward more than half a century to the building of the country's longest highway stretching 5000 kilometres, from Boston to Seattle. I wonder why he thinks we want to hear about some old road, then realise he's leading up to Wallace's second significant act of resistance, and one that has forged the town's collective consciousness.

Wallace fought construction of the Interstate 90 through its centre by placing the entire downtown on the National Register of Historic Places. After holding up completion of the I-90 for 17 years a compromise was finally reached, but in the meantime Wallace got on a roll. Now virtually the whole town is on that register and any new shop-front business must comply with a strict set of aesthetic rules. "There will never be a Starbucks or a McDonald's here," Shaffer says, waving to some locals chugging down the main street on quad bikes, which the council allows and even advertises on its list of 89-plus things to do here (in winter it's snowmobiles). I'm beginning to notice that Wallace makes delicious mincemeat of the numerous stereotypes we hold about modern America. There are no police here, just a county sheriff. This town is so darned sweet, even the port-a-loos are branded Honey Bucket. "It's so weird," the man from Washington says. "It's like everyone who lives here has found home." He looks like he can't wait for that to happen to him, too, as we get up to leave.

The following morning I've got time before meeting Shaffer for a walking tour of town and stop into Angie's Hub at Vintage Games. While Angie makes me a huckleberry shake, I ask if she was born here. "Nope," she tells me, looking happy, "I actively went in search of 'small town America' and just kept coming back to Wallace."

Shaffer meets me at the universe's midpoint and we go from there. Sitting in the town's spaceship, I ask how he became PM and he tells me it began as a joke to a tour group back in 1993. Introducing himself as the US's only prime minister got such a good response he just kept using it. Twelve years later the council made it official and awarded him the city charter. He grins at me across the capsule: "In Wallace, anyone can be anything."

FAST FACTS

Getting there United Airlines flies direct from Sydney to San Francisco with connections to Spokane, Washington. Hire a car from the airport to drive the final 126 kilometres on the I-90 East.

Staying there Stardust Motel is on the cheap and cheerful end from $US60 ($57.70) a night, 410 Pine Street, +1 208 752 1213, stardustmotelidaho.com. Alternatively, Beale House B&B is a charming historic home that isn't into children, from $US170/night, 107 Cedar Street, +1 208 752 7151, wallace-id.com /bealehouse.html.

Touring there Rick Shaffer leads walking tours, driving tours, biking, hiking, ziplining and will even collect you from the airport. Price to be negotiated on booking, +1 800 643 2386, rshaffer@cebridge.net.

While there

Hire a bike and cycle the Idaho-Montana back-country Route of the Hiawatha. See ridethehiawatha.com.

urn:contentItem:4P8H-NPD0-TXN5-S1KV-00000-00Transitions1999-07-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisTODAYPg. 9TransitionsLIFE & TIMES

BURNED. Supreme court judges in New Delhi this week were intoning that 1997 Booker Prize winner Arundhati Roy's latest work - a small book against big dams called The Greater Common Good - is an attack on their dignity. In Gujarat state, Congress party youth activists made a bonfire of the book, and threatened shops that stock it. Roy was waking up to her own part in an environmental struggle of epic proportions: the Narmada Valley project, designed to put 3200 dams on a river that gives life to 25million people. The author's latest bout with controversy started when she put her celebrity - and the 20,000 ($48,500) of her Booker winnings for The God of Small Things - behind the fight to block the dams. Next week she will lead environmental activists visiting some of the 60 villages that will be drowned below the 88-metre walls of the Sardar Sarovar dam.

FOUGHT. The Duchess of York, the former Sarah Ferguson, helped to beat out flames when a forest fire threatened to engulf a villa in Tuscany belonging to the family of her friend Count Gaddo della Gherardesca. The fire was stopped 150 metres from the villa near Livorno on Saturday. At one stage she contacted the British embassy in Rome to help alert authorities. The Duchess was in Tuscany for the wedding of one of the count's cousins. A friend said: "Sarah was to be seen in a T-shirt, shorts and tennis sneakers, frantically rushing round, beating the brush and undergrowth."

ENDANGERED. The Arabian white oryx, saved from extinction earlier this century by one of the world's first successful captive breeding programs, is again under threat. British scientists estimate that poachers have removed or killed at least 200 oryx in the past three years from the central desert in the Sultanate of Oman. Many of the animals are thought to have been taken for private zoos. The return of Oryx leucoryx to Oman in 1982, 10 years after it was exterminated in the wild, was hailed by scientists as a shining example of species conservation - captive breeding followed by reintroducing the animals into the wild.

BARRED. Vladimir Zhirinovsky, the wild man of Russian politics, was barred at the weekend from running for governor of a key Urals region when officials found more than 2000 forged signatures on his nomination papers. Handwriting experts were asked to examine the papers after electoral officials noticed that several Zhirinovsky "supporters" had used an almost identical signature, despite living in different cities of the Sverdlovsk region. Zhirinovsky promised on Saturday that if the signatures were confirmed as forgeries, the local branch of his Liberal Democratic Party would be purged.

Four photos

urn:contentItem:5422-8HM1-DYTG-24HR-00000-00Two books, two generations of life2011-03-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisAPg. 26Two books, two generations of lifeThe Canberra Times

In 2008 in this column I wrote about an Englishwoman, Angela Thirkell, and her novel, Trooper to the Southern Cross. This is the story of the ocean voyage of an Australian soldier and his English bride travelling back to Australia after World War I.

After a failed marriage to Edward McInnes one which yielded two sons, Graham and Colin Angela married an Australian soldier, George Thirkell. Their journey to Australia, with her sons, provided the background for Trooper to the Southern Cross. The family settled in Melbourne. A son, Lance, was born and, in 1929, Angela and Lance returned to England leaving Graham and Colin with their step-father.

She never returned to Australia. I thought this might be a more interesting story than Trooper to the Southern Cross.

A reader wrote to me and recommended a book by the elder son, Graham McInnes, The Road to Gundagai. The reader "had read it as a homesick expat Australian married in London". I have an association with the town of Gundagai so I put the book on my reading list. This year I found a copy in a second-hand bookshop in Fyshwick.

(The only reference to Gundagai in the book is in the lines from Jack O'Hagan's poem from which the title is taken presumably to identify the book as Australian.)

When Angela and George Thirkell, and the two boys, arrived in Australia in 1920 they lived briefly in Hobart before moving to Melbourne. The narrative of The Road to Gundagai is an account of a boy, Graham McInnes, growing up in suburban Melbourne in the 1920s. I was surprised to find aspects of this boyhood that were similar to my own boyhood in country towns of NSW in the 1940s and 1950s. Two of the most vivid were school teachers throwing blackboard dusters at misbehaving pupils and the recalcitrant behaviour of "chip heaters" used to heat bathwater. I identified with McInnes's descriptions of rabbit-trapping and his struggle with the discipline of a boy scout troop. Girls were reading books of the Billabong series by Mary Grant Bruce also popular with my sisters and both McInnes and myself were keen readers of the exploits of "Sapper's" Bulldog Drummond.

I noted McInnes's description of the country near the Victorian village of Kinglake. "A forest fire ten years before had cleared away the timber, leaving sweeping slopes of bracken with here and there charred sentinels lifting against the sky as a reminder of the former forest."

While The Road to Gundagai is the story of Graham McInnes's life, he does give glimpses of his parents' characters before final chapters that deal with Angela and George Thirkell in more detail. As they moved into their Melbourne home, McInnes writes, "Mother had an invincible contempt for things Australian and made no bones about it ... her relationship with shopkeepers, officials, neighbours and local tradespeople, was an unending guerrilla warfare", and a couple of chapters later: "Mother [had] taken the view that, broadly speaking, nothing worthwhile ever happened in Melbourne." His final word on his mother is that he has "wonderfully amusing, witty and loving letters from her; but to be demonstrative, in person, ah! That was different."

McInnes enjoyed a much warmer relationship with his step- father. He refers to him as "Dad" or "Thirk" throughout the book. At mealtimes, "Mother presided and carved: Dad, who was rarely in on time, ate and talked." Similarly, "With Mother everything was sharp and tight and on schedule ... with Dad it was a world of laissez- faire, sudden impulses, tuneless cheerful whistling, odd tasks begun and never finished ... Dad never paid a school bill of mine in his life ... but if you wanted ten bob suddenly ... " Angela Thirkell realised that she and George were incompatible and returned to England. Maybe she also realised that Graham and Colin were closer to their step-father than herself. However, a couple of years later, Colin McInnes followed his mother back to England.

Graham stayed in Melbourne. He completed a university degree on scholarship, married and in 1934 and this came as a shock to me as I read the book set out "to join my own father in far off Canada ... with the memory of Dad's mournful face receding among the girders and grimy glass of Spencer Street Railway Station". I'm not interested in reading Graham McInnes's later book about finding his "own father".

Nor am I interested in any of Angela Thirkell's or Colin McInnes's novels. Yes, my sympathies are all with "Dad" the forsaken George Thirkell.

I wrote a letter to the reader who had recommended The Road to Gundagai to me.

I wanted to thank her for writing to me about it and I wanted to ask her if she knew of a book about the rest of George Thirkell's life.

Sadly, my letter was returned to me "not known at this address".

urn:contentItem:7XV1-MWH1-2RG6-Y55R-00000-00Royal Commission hears fuel loads led to bushfire deaths2010-02-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisPM6:32 PM AESTABCSamantha DonovanRoyal Commission hears fuel loads led to bushfire deaths

MARK COLVIN: The Royal Commission into the Black Saturday disaster has heard today that Victoria remains "dangerously unprepared" to tackle major bushfires. There was also evidence that there are just not enough fire-fighters to meet the government's own fuel reduction targets.

The Australian Workers Union told the Commission that the Victorian Government had broken a 2004 promise to boost the number of firefighters protecting public land.

Lawyers acting for the Victorian Government didn't challenge any of the union's claims.

Samantha Donovan reports.

SAMANTHA DONOVAN: Fuel reduction on public land in Victoria is one of the most contentious issues for the Royal Commission to consider. Athol Hodgson is a forest fire expert and a former chief fire officer with what was once the Victorian Department of Conservation. He was blunt in his assessment to the Commission.

ATHOL HODGSON: The Government of Victoria with respect to public land management has allowed fuel levels to accumulate to levels that I believe are quiet unnatural and they've accumulated to the levels and got so dry on a, in a period of drought that it became impossible to stop some fires unless you were standing beside them when they started.

And those unnaturally high levels of fuel contributed significantly to the fact that people died in large numbers in a very short space of time.

SAMANTHA DONOVAN: The Commission heard today that the Victorian Department of Sustainability and Environment currently burns less than two per cent of Victorian forests to reduce fuels. But its own corporate plan says a desirable target is two to three times that.

Mr Hodgson asked the Commission to recommend that the state almost triple its fuel reduction burns and enshrine the targets in legislation so performance can be accurately assessed. The Australian Workers Union represents field staff and fire-fighters employed by state government departments.

The secretary of the Victorian branch, Cesar Melhem told the Commission that the state is "tragically unprepared" for another Black Saturday. He said the number of fire-fighters has fallen dramatically since the 1980s and '90s.

CESAR MELHEM: It's a huge difference, I mean as you said, the numbers back has fallen from a shameful 257 to a 237 notwithstanding the government promise to increase this number.

SAMANTHA DONOVAN: The current statistics of the Victorian DepDepartmentt of Sustainability and Environment put the number of staff at 3,000. But Cesar Melhem says the figures are misleading.

CESAR MELHEM: It's fine to have all these good numbers, 3,065 but we need to really look at how many actual fire-fighters, how many field staff, there's too many chiefs and less fire-fighters. You can't go and fight a war with a part -time army. You need a fully trained professional fire-fighters to prepare us and the resources are not there.

SAMANTHA DONOVAN: Counsel assisting the Commission, Rachel Doyle showed the Union's Cesar Melhem a 2004 Victorian government press release. It announced that 200 new staff would be employed to work on fire fighting and prevention over the next four years.

Mr Melhem said at the time he understood that to mean an extra 151 field crew would be employed.

CESAR MELHEM: But unfortunately they have broken that promise and we've only seen an increase of 23 field fire-fighters and we're waiting, we're still waiting for the other 128.

SAMANTHA DONOVAN: Lawyers acting for the Victorian Government didn't cross-examine Mr Melhem on any of the union's claims. But examined by senior counsel assisting the Commission, Jack Rush QC, the secretary of the Department of Sustainability and Environment, Greg Wilson acknowledged the department was reviewing its staffing levels.

GREG WILSON: We've got staffing submissions before the Government that go to questions about resources into the future which I'm unable to talk about from a cabinet and confidence point of view but we're certainly building our resources, building our capability and getting better at it.

The Government will want to look at the findings of the Commission and a whole range of other factors, I suspect, before it makes definitive decisions about resources in response to the proposals that we've put to them recently.

MARK COLVIN: Greg Wilson, secretary of the Victorian Department of Sustainability and Environment ending Samantha Donovan's report.

urn:contentItem:4P89-SFP0-TXN5-V2T6-00000-00Radio failure caused death1999-06-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 3Radio failure caused deathJENNY DENNIS

Volunteer firefighter David Quinlivan died needlessly in a forest fire at Wingello as a result of a simple breakdown in radio communications, a coroner's inquest in Bowral has found.

NSW senior deputy state coroner John Abernethy found a communication failure at a vital time early in the fire caused precious minutes to be lost - minutes he believed would have allowed Mr Quinlivan and the seven crew members injured that day to make their escape safely.

Presenting his findings yesterday, Mr Abernethy said the communication failure between the fire controller and the tanker crew played a "fundamental role" in the incident on New Year's Day, 1998.

"I am confident that, had normal communications been available at all relevant times, the incident would have been avoided and the death of Mr Quinlivan would not have occurred," he said.

In the one recommendation he made, Mr Abernethy concentrated on the communication breakdown, recommending the RFS fully investigate the problem with a view to establishing a probable cause for the failure.

The coroner was unable to say why communications had failed, adding that if the RFS possessed any further evidence it should have been placed before the inquest.

"I assume it has not, and wonder why it has not taken more care in attempting to ascertain the most likely cause of the failure, be it weather conditions, heat or any other factor," he said.

Mr Abernethy said equipment used that day was "inferior" citing, in particular, burns experienced by the Wingello survivors which were caused by excessive heat to reflective tape and brigade logos on overalls they had been issued.

The coroner said there were no grounds for criticism of either John Luke Snr, group captain of the local Wingecarribee Rural Fire Service Brigade, or Gabrielle Clatworthy, the young forestry worker who found herself in charge of the fire by virtue of

the fact that it occurred on State Forestry-administered land.

Nor was there any criticism of Mr Quinlivan's actions that day.

"Mr Quinlivan was in a most difficult position," Mr Abernethy said.

"He did not panic, but bravely continued to operate his vehicle, for the good of all inside it, until he could no longer do so.'

The coroner found Mr Quinlivan died in the driver's seat of Wingello One after being overcome by smoke. He said the 45-year-old father of three deserved high commendation for his actions and said he trusted the RFS would now take the appropriate steps to honour him.

Three illus: David Quinlivan's widow Leanne Scurr leaves Bowral court yesterday. Picture: WAYNE VENABLES NSW RFS Commissioner Phil Koperberg (right) speaks to Wingecarribee fire brigade captain John Luke Snr. Picture: WAYNE VENABLES MR QUINLIVAN

urn:contentItem:4MSB-85W0-TX52-J2WC-00000-00Fires leave the sounds of silence2007-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisOPEDITPg. 19Fires leave the sounds of silenceTony Cutcliffe

VICTORIA'S continuing bushfires are heading for a million hectares of destruction.

This is alarming, but it is the silence that follows the fires that is is frightening.

The incinerated native animals and the absent birds are silent, and so are the leafless trees.

The loudest silence comes from the various green groups that are protecting their political influence.

It is time for some inconvenient truths.

For example, Victoria has about seven million hectares of state forests and national parks. Much of it was formerly managed by the old SECV and the Forestry Commission.

Regular, managed burning reduced fuel levels and when a bushfire did start it was fought with local volunteers.

When these organisations disappeared the resources dried up and governments refused to take up the slack.

The fuel load builds up to crisis levels, fires start and the Department of Sustainability and Environment does not have enough people to put them out.

The problem gets worse because paid CFA executives have squeezed out experienced and knowledgeable local volunteers.

Authorities have let fire trails return to nature and fire crews cannot reach fires.

Instead of fighting the fires, huge bulldozed containment lines are ripped into the forest around the fire perimeter.

At one stage during the current fires some 60 bulldozers were reported to be going flat out.

As the fires spread, countless wild animals, plants and insect colonies are destroyed.

The ground cover is killed, seeds get washed away and much of the forest gets replaced with grassland.

These days the Man from Snowy River might ride a lawnmower.

The greens are also quiet about the competition between native species and introduced feral pests.

For example, some of the first vegetation to return after the fires is the noxious blackberry vine, which fuels much of the fire in the first place.

Native animals struggling to recover get crowded out by introduced pests such as the big samba deer and wild goats, dogs and brumbies.

It is estimated there are more than 200,000 such pests in the fire country. Yet they are effectively protected because killing more than a handful might cause protests in the city.

INSTEAD, the mountain cattlemen get painted as vandals, even though they used to graze as few as 6000 cattle for 16 weeks a year.

The president of Forest Fire Victoria, Athol Hodgson, correctly observes that country people have been isolated from the protection and maintenance of public land.

The huge risk for Melbourne relates to the security of water supply.

The current fires actually reached the Thomson River catchment, which supplies most of Melbourne's water.

It is only a matter of time before the catchment burns and Melbourne University's Dr Peter Attiwill says regrowth will reduce stream flows by 30 to 50 per cent.

If the catchment does burn, the remaining water will be contaminated with ash and silt and it will be like drinking from an ashtray.

Such a disaster in the middle of a drought could see household water restricted to a trickle.

Some people would need to move to find water and Victoria's water chasers would become Australia's first environmental refugees.

Victorians must be allowed to have an informed debate about forest management so that our environmental treasures receive the resources and management they need.

That debate would also restore some respect for the role played by country volunteers in preserving public land.

It might also help to persuade self-styled greens they aren't the only ones who care about the bush.

tc@eurekaoz.com

TONY CUTCLIFFE is a director of forum and consultancy, the Eureka Project

urn:contentItem:4P84-VK40-TXN5-R1RV-00000-00Spins1999-03-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisTIME OUTPg. 21SpinsSoundsPeter Holmes

The Collection

Lloyd Cole (Mercury)

HE may have spent the 1990s wearing trench coats and smoking cigars in New York, but Lloyd Cole's good name will always be linked with the collection of songs he recorded, and partly co-wrote, with his British band The Commotions in the 1980s. With a melancholy, detached vocal style and a habit of moulding pretentious, stream-of-consciousness lyrics into genuinely touching laments, Cole needed musicians to bring his literate tales to life. From the stark organ and vocal arrangement of the bitter hymn Forest Fire to the sparkling, pristine pop singles Rattlesnakes, Lost Weekend and My Bag, The Commotions made it happen with brevity, inventiveness and style. Cole should never have left them, for the quality of his solo work since the elegant early single No Blue Skies has generally tapered off. 8/10

Cross reference: The Triffids, Ron Sexsmith, Aztec Camera

The Islander

Dave Dobbyn (Columbia/Sony)

WAY too un-hip for the national youth network (Triple J) and subject to the extreme caution displayed by 2DAY and Triple M's music directors, it is little wonder an artist such as Dave Dobbyn finds himself existing in a void. One quality release follows another, only to be feted in his homeland of New Zealand and stupidly ignored here. It is sad because Dobbyn, founding member of DD Smash and best-known for his cheesy 1980s hit Slice Of Heaven, owns a soulful vocal and writes a mean pop song. Highlights include Waiting, which comes on like a Blur out-take from the early 1990s, and the gentle, melodic acoustic hops Mobile Home and Hanging In The Wire. 7/10

Cross reference: Neil Finn, Blur, The Bodeans

Sister And Brother

Melky Sedeck (MCA/Universal)

AS with their older brother, the Fugees' Wyclef Jean, Blandinna "Melky" Jean and Farel "Sedeck" Jean were raised in a strict Christian household in Brooklyn, New York. Sister And Brother is a hip-hop soul collection that swings effortlessly between contemporary middle-of-the-road raps and timeless, Motown-inspired r 'n' b. With smart use of strings, odd keyboard noises, guitars and mouth harp and sharp vocal arrangements, Melky Sedeck manage to save the so-so songs from complete blandness. However, the programmed beats are way too thin. 6/10

Cross reference: Maxwell, Gladys Knight, The Fugees

Various

Aussie Rock (Warner)

DESPITE the dodgy spelling on the sleeve notes Aussie Rock provides a pleasurable enough mosey down memory lane. Highlights include Spectrum's plodding classic I'll Be Gone, Masters Apprentices' swinging garage stomp Turn Up Your Radio, Australian Crawl's atmospheric ballad Reckless, Mi-Sex's early synth exploration Computer Games and Max Merritt & The Meteors'

heartbreaker Slipping Away. 8/10

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Vic: Fires may have been deliberately lit</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Susan Murdoch</nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>MELBOURNE, Jan 22</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Fires which destroyed four houses in Victoria's north-east overnight, and continue to rage out of control, are believed to have been deliberately lit.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Country Fire Authority (CFA) chief fire officer Russell Rees said three fires began in quick succession, destroying four houses and a shed at Yackandandah, Stanley and in the Indigo Valley.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"The origin of these fires are suspicious … and are being investigated by police," Mr Rees told reporters.</p><p>More than 20,000ha has now been burned at Eldorado, and up to 4,000ha was razed in Stanley, with the flames racing through grassland, scrub, plantation pines and box ironbark country.</p><p>However, Mr Rees said given there were 130 houses directly in the path of the fires, the efforts of firefighters and the community had worked well.</p><p>"It's outstanding that the losses were so small," he said.</p><p>By mid afternoon, the Eldorado and Stanley fires had slowed along the frontlines and firefighters were controlling them from the flanks.</p><p>Relief centres have been established at Wodonga, Chiltern, Beechworth, Myrtleford and Bright for residents who have fled their homes.</p><p>Mr Rees said firefighters were working frantically ahead of forecast extreme conditions over the weekend, but he said with conditions so dry after five years of drought, the fires were continuing to burn regardless of the temperature or wind direction.</p><p>"There has been 15 days of solid fires, in my view there is no end in sight," Mr Rees said.</p><p>Meanwhile, exhausted crews in Victoria's north-eastern alpine areas, where lightning strikes started a series of fires earlier this month, were today relieved with reinforcements arriving from around the state.</p><p>A team of forest fire experts from New Zealand had also been deployed to the Gippsland fires near Omeo, which were burning through dense, rugged country.</p><p>The threat to the township of Bright eased overnight and firefighters were able to hold control lines around the blaze, now burning on a 100km front.</p><p>Mr Rees praised the efforts of the CFA and reminded employers that it was crucial volunteers continued to be made available.</p><p>Meanwhile, residents in several streets at Lysterfield in Melbourne's east were today urged to activate their bushfire plans.</p><p>CFA spokesman Peter Philp said the grass and bushland fire remained within containment lines but residents - dressed appropriately in heavy duty clothes - were urged to extinguish any falling embers.</p><p>DSE spokesman Stuart Ord later said the fire threat to the townships of Bright, Porepunkah and Wandiligong had flared again this afternoon and crews were preparing for erratic fire behaviour.</p><p>Residents were urged to stay and defend their property or leave immediately, with the Buffalo fire now burning just 2km south-west of Bright.</p><p>"The fire is becoming extremely erratic and hard to predict," he said.</p><p>"With hot conditions expected this weekend the fire intensity may well increase."</p><p>Mr Ord said humidity in the region was down to just four per cent.</p><p>Meanwhile, residents at Harrietville were urged to activate their fire plans and remain on high alert with spot fires from the Bogong bushfire slowly heading towards the Alpine hamlet.<br/></p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:59NK-G941-F0J6-J3PM-00000-00Volunteer firey kept feet on ground as he rose to the top2013-10-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisNEWS REVIEWPg. 5Volunteer firey kept feet on ground as he rose to the topRick Feneley

Fire claimed his father's life but also gave him his wife and his wider 'family'. Rick Feneley profiles RFS Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons.

It was another fire emergency, 10 or more years ago. Shane Fitzsimmons, already a senior manager or "white shirt" at the Rural Fire Service, had put in some hard hours. Then commissioner Phil Koperberg told him: "Shane, whether you like it or not, you're going home. You need to rest. I need you at your best."

"He reluctantly agreed," Koperberg recalled this week. "Then I happened to go out where the fires were and I found him on a fire truck." There he was, fighting a fire with the "yellow overalls". "I said, 'This doesn't look like a bed to me.' "

Koperberg would go on to anoint Fitzsimmons as his successor in 2007. "This week's event was his trial by fire, if you'll pardon the pun, and he has emerged from it soundly - exceptionally."

On Friday last week, the day after firestorms erupted and razed 208 homes, Premier Barry O'Farrell appeared before the cameras with Fitzsimmons. "I was behind him when he broke up at the lectern, when he was asked how his volunteers and paid firefighters were coping," O'Farrell tells the Herald. This display of emotion was a potent scene: the unflappable Fitzsimmons - the stoic who would stand at that lectern eight times a day over the next week and deliver the grim news in monotone - suddenly overwhelmed, gulping back tears before they could flow, the Premier placing a supporting hand on his shoulder.

O'Farrell reasons: "When you hear the Fitzsimmons story, particularly about the loss of his dad, he does not have to be reminded about the risks that are involved in firefighting."

Shane Fitzsimmons was 15 when he joined the Duffys Forest Rural Fire Brigade in northern Sydney. He volunteered so he could fight bushfires alongside his father, George, a full-time firey. Young Shane was enthralled. George Fitzsimmons worked with fire-prevention crews from the Warringah Control Centre. The centre's fire control officer was Keith Simpson, whose daughter Lisa worked on the radio. Shane and Lisa would become teenage sweethearts, then husband and wife.

Shane got his trade as a motor mechanic but never stopped his RFS volunteer work. He was in his 20s when Koperberg met him at Warringah in 1994. The commissioner told his executive assistant: "This young man has real potential. We need to bring him in."

Within two years, Fitzsimmons had become the RFS state operations officer and in 1998 he was appointed assistant commissioner responsible for operations. His father, a yellow-overalls man who had been awarded the National Fire Medal, would give him the gee-up for being a white shirt. They were close. George was a young father. Only 21 years separated him and his son.

George was 52 when he and three other firemen were killed during what was meant to be a routine hazard-reduction burn in Ku-ring-gai Chase National Park on June 8, 2000. While media reports suggested George had led his trapped party uphill, contrary to procedure, the coroner exonerated him and found he had trusted an inaccurate map.

Shane was working that day and Koperberg remembers: "There was an immediate flood of support for him to go and attend to his own personal loss. Shane has never been one to walk away from his post at a time of adversity."

That tragedy must inform the compassion he feels for firefighters, the burden of responsibility he carries for them, and the displays of emotion, Koperberg and O'Farrell say.

Fitzsimmons acknowledges this when he finds a few minutes for the Herald on Thursday night. He is not long off the phone to the wife of David Black, a father of three killed that day when his plane crashed while fighting fires on the south coast. Hours earlier, Fitzsimmons had again struggled to compose his emotion before the cameras when he said the pilot's children would soon have to understand why "their dad hasn't come home".

"I think the experience I went through and the families of the other men went through - I became close to them - it's an ordeal you wouldn't wish upon anybody," he says. "I can't think of a more horrifying way to go than to be incinerated in a fire."

So didn't he want to quit after his father's death? "I did for a fleeting moment think, 'Why do this?' But I remember it strengthened my resolve to say, 'No, you can't stand on the outside and pontificate. If you want to make a difference, you have to get in there.' "

Koperberg, who spent 21 years as commissioner from 1985, and who went on to become a state Labor minister, saw early that Fitzsimmons could make a difference. He saw the same qualities in another volunteer he hand-picked, Rob Rogers. Koperberg exposed both men to wide-ranging experience in middle and senior management. "This was part of my succession planning." Rogers is now deputy commissioner. O'Farrell has called back Koperberg to co-ordinate the recovery in the Blue Mountains.

At RFS headquarters, Fitzsimmons presents as a man with old-fashioned manners; after one of his news conferences - the first is at 7.05am, the last at 8.05pm - he opens the door for a stampede of journalists rushing to file stories. In the kitchen, he refers to Ally, the woman making coffee, by name. "He doesn't hold airs and graces," Keith Simpson, his father-in-law, says. "He's not someone who looks for accolades. He's just a firey."

Shane and Lisa Fitzsimmons have two daughters, Lauren, 16, and Sarah, 13. He has considered entering politics "to the extent that I want to serve the community. But then I see what happens to politicians today and I think, 'Why would you?"'

He adds: "I'm lucky. I've grown up in the RFS. I found my wife through this organisation. The RFS is family. I love what it stands for. I love what its people stand for - and I love them for what they do."

urn:contentItem:49NB-0KK0-01S8-D3J4-00000-00<published>1992-06-08T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:55Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Report sparks bushfire alert</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>TROETH S</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">VICTORIANS will face a bushfire threat equal to the 1983 Ash Wednesday inferno every summer because of the greenhouse effect, according to new research.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> A CSIRO and Monash University study of the effect of an expected doubling of carbon dioxide levels during the next century because of the greenhouse effect showed an increase in fire risk across most of Victoria.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Firefighters said yesterday they will move faster on implementing new fire control measures, including Neigborhood Watch-style community groups, because of the data.</p><p>Victoria already has one of the most severe fire climates in the world, recording 72 per cent of Australia's 467 wildfire deaths since 1900 and a yearly average annual property loss of $51 million since 1970.</p><p> In the Ash Wednesday fires in February 1983, 46 people died and 1511 houses were burnt, leaving a damage bill of almost $500 million.</p><p> CSIRO bushfire research unit scientist Dr Tom Beer said a drop in relative humidity - a major factor in bushfire risk - would come with the greenhouse effect.</p><p> The atmosphere would heat and carbon dioxide levels would jump as the protective ozone layer was depleted.</p><p> The model predicted large areas of Victoria would become more fire-prone, with East Gippsland recording the largest increase in the Forest Fire Danger Index.</p><p> "East Gippsland would experience a 38 per cent rise in the index if the carbon dioxide level were to double during the next century," Dr Beer said.</p><p> "Almost every summer, that would raise the fire danger in this region to a value as high as those experienced on Ash Wednesday." Senior fire control officers say work will be speeded up on new firefighting procedures, including a co-operative commmunity-based approach to protection.</p><p> The chief fire officer at the Conservation and Environment Department, Mr Rod Incoll, said the study had added new urgency to fire prevention work.</p><p> He said a Neighborhood Watch-style program was high on the agenda as two-thirds of wildfires were caused by people.</p><p> There will be closer links between the department and the Country Fire Authority and a more ecologically-based fire prevention approach.</p><p> "Fire prevention needs to be seen as a whole community responsibility and the CSIRO information showed that this would become more essential as climate change progressed," Mr Incoll said.</p><p> Rio summit fears, Page 7</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4P7G-YGD0-TXN5-R21J-00000-00BUSHFIRE RAGES ON IN CHINA, BUT CITY OF 100,000 ESCAPES1987-05-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 10BUSHFIRE RAGES ON IN CHINA, BUT CITY OF 100,000 ESCAPESROBERT THOMSON, Staff Correspondent

BEIJING, Wednesday: The huge forest fire, which has already claimed 168 lives and is the largest in China for at least four decades, has turned away from a northern city of 100,000 people, but it was still out of control on several fronts late today.

Yesterday, the blaze reached the outskirts of Tahe, in Heilongjiang province, near the Sino-Soviet border, prompting another 10,000 soldiers and volunteers to join the 15,000 people already fighting the fire.

Fortunately, the wind dropped and Tahe, which Chinese officials had said was in "serious danger", is now safe.

Firefighters and soldiers are being parachuted into thick forest to cut firebreaks, while several planes have been seeding clouds in the area in the hope of encouraging rain.

Since the fire began last Wednesday, about 300 people have been injured, 51,000 have been left homeless and 400,000 hectares of forest has been destroyed.

Xilinji, a town with a population of 20,000, has been razed, and 20,000 people have been evacuated from in and around Tahe, which has been protected by a 20 kilometre-long firebreak.

The blaze apparently began when a faulty forest clearing machine caught fire on a farm close to the border, and it has been fanned by strong winds in recent days.

Forestry officials are attempting to bring the fire under control before the weekend, when the central weather bureau again predicts strong winds.

Snowfalls are expected in the next day or so, and a Vice-Premier, Mr Li Peng, who is visiting the afflicted area, has said that Saturday is the deadline for extinguishing the fire.

The far north-west corner of Heilongjiang is mostly forest, but it is a sensitive military zone and off-limits to foreigners because of its closeness to the Sino-Soviet border.

A Chinese forestry official said the Soviet Union had not been asked to assist and he did not think that its help would be needed.

urn:contentItem:4C94-C410-015G-P1X7-00000-00<published>2004-05-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:55Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD-BIOG- STING, GORDON SUMNER; Pg. 13</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>You've all been stung, says frantic sex practitioner Sting</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>* Richard Brooks</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">* London</p><p nitf:lede="true">EVERYONE knows Sting practises epic bouts of tantric sex with his wife, Trudie Styler, because the couple have often boasted about it.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> But it seems there has been some mistake. What he really meant was "frantic" sex.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>The Sunday Times</p></bodyText></section><p>In an interview to be broadcast next week on the BBC, Sting confesses that the whole story of how he used yoga to achieve prolonged states of ecstasy was "a joke".</p><p> Asked if he knows what tantric sex is, Sting, whose real name is Gordon Sumner, replies: "I haven't a clue."</p><p> Lest it be thought this means he isn't as virile as he has been portrayed, Sting insists he has a lively sex life. "I have frantic sex, which is just as good as tantric sex." The myth of Mr and Mrs Sumner's tantric sex has been traced to a dinner party they attended with Irish rock stars Bob Geldof and Bono. Sting has previously attributed his boast to a drunken night out, but he supplies the details for the first time. "It was simply me and Geldof bitching," says Sting, whose hits include Roxanne and Don't Stand So Close to Me.</p><p> "We were chatting and talking about having hours of sex. It then became really a joke that went around the world like a forest fire."</p><p> Geldof has given his version of events in a separate interview. "We did have a few drinks together," concedes the former Boomtown Rat, now better known for his interest in Third World issues. "I said to Sting, 'Why would you want it for eight hours? It must be so boring. She (Trudie) must have said, 'Get on with it'."</p><p> According to Geldof, it was Sting who enthused about prolonged sex. To which Geldof replied: "Thirty seconds, that's enough, that'll do me."</p><p> Styler, who works as a movie producer and environmentalist, landed herself in hot water recently when talking about her sex life on US radio.</p><p> Interviewed by shock-jock Howard Stern, she said she and her husband enjoyed wife-swapping, and that she liked the attentions of women.</p><p> When Stern asked, "Are you guys still swinging?" Styler replied, "Yes, big time, honey."</p><p> Stern's sidekick on the program, Robin Quivers, inquired if the 49-year-old mother of four knew what swinging meant. Styler responded, "Swinging is like wife-swapping, right? Of course we're doing it."</p><p> She told Stern that she and her ex-Police frontman spiced up their love life by watching Sting meeting other women at sex clubs. But a couple of days after her interview on US radio, Styler came clean, admitting the whole thing had been a hoax. "I was joking, for goodness sake," she said.</p><p> Now well into middle age, Mr and Mrs Sumner seem finally to have put to bed the stories about their love-making.</p><p> Quite why they allowed these urban myths to spread, and are now so keen to deny them, probably only a sex counsellor or psychotherapist would know.</p><p> Geldof may have the answer: "It's like tantric shopping. You go out looking at the shop windows all day and buy nothing."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P8H-NPK0-TXN5-S070-00000-00TRANSITIONS1998-07-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:56ZLexisNexisLIVINGPg. 20TRANSITIONSMILESTONES

DISSENTED. The most vocal critic of the way Japan's Liberal Democratic Party is selecting its leader is not the opposition, the media or the markets, but an influential party member whose father was the master of the back-room deal. Makiko Tanaka, daughter of the late Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka, is not only an influential woman in a male-dominated environment, she is also outspoken. "This election will decide whether the LDP can change itself, but the candidates merely give speeches. There is no debate. We need to be more open," she said this week as a stream of senior politicians traipsed into her office to canvass her support. The influence of her father, who built up the party's most-powerful faction, is still strong and Ms Tanaka is said to have the support of about 20 LDP legislators.

CRUISING. As the battle for the non-permanent seats on the UN Security Council hots up, Greek suntans are the order of the day at the United Nations. More than 110 UN ambassadors have accepted an invitation from the Greek Government to take their families on an all-expenses-paid Aegean cruise. The invitations are ostensibly aimed at boosting international support for an Olympic truce centre to be located at Olympia in southern Greece, the historic seat of the Olympic Games. But nobody has any doubts that the initiative is part of Greece's bid to secure a non-permanent seat on the Security Council when the 185-nation UN General Assembly votes on the new members in November.

ENDANGERED. The health risk to tens of thousands of Indonesians hit by smoky haze last year may be more severe than expected, US Environmental Protection Agency officials warned this week. "We have every reason to project that there probably was a much more substantial public health impact, a much more likely increased mortality among these people, and increased hospital admissions," Lester Grant, director of the EPA's Environmental Criteria and Assessment Office, said. The EPA based its conclusions on studies of forest fire haze in large areas of the region. It found that for Malaysia and Singapore the health risk was less severe.

DIAGNOSED. Medical tests conducted on Jordan's King Hussein at a hospital in the United States suggest the 62-year-old monarch has cancer, the king told his brother, Crown Prince Hassan ibn Talal, in a letter made public in Amman. "All the indications lead one to believe that I have a lymphoma," wrote the king, adding that he was about to "undergo chemotherapy". The king had said in a note to his brother that doctors at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minnesota, expected to reach a precise diagnosis after obtaining the laboratory tests.

urn:contentItem:51MS-FS21-DYG0-92XX-00000-00Highlights of the AAP world wire at 08:00 Dec 62010-12-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:56ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSHighlights of the AAP world wire at 08:00 Dec 6

  HIGHLIGHTS WORLD (ATTN EDITORS)
Highlights of the AAP world file since 20:00
WikiLeaks safeguards data
   WASHINGTON, Dec 5 AFP - WikiLeaks, the website infuriating Washington for releasing hundreds of restricted US diplomatic cables, was making all its archives so far available for download as pressure mounted to close it down entirely. (WIKILEAKS Update sent at 08:05, 657 words.)


Prosecutor defends move against Assange
   STOCKHOLM, Dec 5 AFP - Sweden's investigation of rape allegations against WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange is "completely independent" and not politically influenced, the prosecutor handling the case says. (WIKILEAKS ASSANGE sent at 05:12, 449 words.)
'Political motivations' in Assange hunt
   LONDON, Dec 5 AFP - The hunt for WikiLeaks' founder Julian Assange has "political motivations", his lawyer said on Sunday, as secret US cables released by the whistleblowing website linked China's top propagandist to Google cyber attacks. (WIKILEAKS sent at 04:09, 516 words.)
Saudi Arabia `finance base for al-Qaeda'
   RIYADH, Dec 5 AFP - Saudi Arabia is the key source of funding for radical Islamist groups, including al-Qaeda, the Taliban, Lashkar-e-Toiba and Hamas, according to US diplomatic cables released by WikiLeaks on Sunday. (WIKILEAKS SAUDI sent at 04:45, 585 words.)
WikiLeaks uses Swiss Web address as option
   GENEVA, Dec 6 AP - WikiLeaks' elusive Australian founder, his options dwindling, has turned to Switzerland's credit, postal and internet infrastructure to keep his online trove of US State Department cables afloat. (WIKILEAKS ASSANGE (Newsfeature) sent at 07:51, 899 words.)
Four soldiers die in Afghan attack
   KHOST, Afghanistan, Dec 5 AFP - Two NATO and two Afghan soldiers have been killed in a suicide attack at a market close to a joint military base in the east of the country. (AFGHAN BLAST sent at 00:51, 465 words.)
Iran declares nuclear 'self-sufficiency'
   TEHRAN, Dec 5 AFP - Iran says it has produced a first batch of uranium yellowcake, the raw material for enrichment, in a move it says "strengthens" its position before talks with world powers on its controversial nuclear program. (IRAN NUCLEAR sent at 04:39, 717 words.)
Flood chaos in Balkans
   BERLIN, Dec 5 AFP - An early cold snap slowly released Europe from its icy grip on Sunday after days of mayhem and dozens of deaths, but floods displaced thousands in the Balkans and chaos still hit Spanish airports. (EUROPE WEATHER Update sent at 08:10, 680 words.)
Sub-Arctic fires a climate change risk
   PARIS, Dec 5 AFP - Global warming is driving forest fires in northern latitudes to burn more frequently and fiercely, contributing to the threat of runaway climate change, according to a study. (CLIMATE FIRES sent at 05:19, 620 words.)
Israel brings deadly blaze under control
   HAIFA, Israel, Dec 5 AFP - Firefighters have brought under control the deadly blaze which tore through a forest in northern Israel after a four-day battle aided by aircraft from the around the world, officials say. (ISRAEL FIRE sent at 04:12, 535 words.)
Residents flee Lebanon forest fire
   FATRI, Lebanon, Dec 5 AFP - Firefighters in Lebanon battled a forest blaze on Sunday that has raged out of control for the past week, and frightened villagers north of Beirut fled as flames threatened to engulf their homes. (LEBANON FIRE sent at 03:34, 336 words.)
Chilean miner: Movie discussions advanced
   SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec 5 AP - Two of the 33 Chilean miners trapped underground for two months say plans for a movie chronicling their ordeal are moving fast. (CHILE MINE sent at 07:57, 214 words.)
Rivals declare new I.Coast govt
   ABIDJAN, Dec 5 AFP - Rivals challenging Laurent Gbagbo's claim to the presidency of Ivory Coast say they had formed a new government, as international mediators try to settle the standoff amid fears of civil war. (ICOAST VOTE Update sent at 07:00, 687 words.)
Russian satellites crash into Pacific
   MOSCOW, Dec 5 AFP - Three Russian navigation satellites have crashed into the Pacific off Hawaii after the rocket carrying them failed to reach orbit, a Russian space official quoted by the Ria-Novosti agency said. (RUSSIA SATELLITES sent at 04:09, 343 words.)
EU doesn't believe in Afghan success: memo
   BRUSSELS, Dec 5 AP - Leaked diplomatic memos say European Union President Herman Van Rompuy told America's ambassador that the EU no longer believes in success in Afghanistan, and that European troops are still there "out of deference to the United States". (WIKILEAKS AFGHAN sent at 02:17, 187 words.)
Car kills eight cyclists in Italy
   ROME, Dec 5 AP - A speeding car has plowed head-on into a group of cyclists in southern Italy, killing eight of them. (ITALY CYCLISTS sent at 02:00, 230 words.)
People clog Spain airports as strike ends

urn:contentItem:46SF-P8T0-015G-T2JT-00000-00<published>2002-09-17T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:56Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 15</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Safe but sore after fall</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>PHILIP CULLEN</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Counting cost of high wind</p><p nitf:lede="true">A CHRISTMAS Hills woman thrown from the roof of her home as it lifted in ferocious wind said yesterday that she was sore but thankful to be alive.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Katrina Brain, 28, was knocked out after being catapulted 10m to the ground on Sunday after getting on to the roof of her home to repair a chimney flue.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "I pushed the flue back in and when I turned back the whole roof was coming up like a tidal wave coming to get me," she said from her Austin hospital bed yesterday.</p><p>Ms Brain said she regained consciousness in the arms of a friend, Carl, as he was calling an ambulance. She suffered a broken pelvis, cuts and bruises.</p><p> "I realise now I could have died. I was wrapped up in it, it rolled me up as the roof peeled," she said.</p><p> Gusts of more than 100km/h that buffeted the state for the second time this month were coupled with the warmest start to spring on record.</p><p> The State Emergency Service took 850 calls from Sunday afternoon, mostly for damaged roofs and fallen trees and powerlines.</p><p> Volunteers were called to more than 100 jobs in the Ballarat area, including a fallen 100-year-old willow tree and the collapse of a brick wall.</p><p> Wind, which peaked at 140km/h at Mt Hotham, also fanned fires across the state.</p><p> Before the temperature dropped and rain fell across the state yesterday, firefighters battled almost 100 blazes. Yesterday they warned of a disastrous fire season if forecasts of below-average rainfall in coming months proved correct.</p><p> Country Fire Authority volunteers saved 10 homes in Apollo Bay from a blaze that burned 550ha of dense scrub along the Gellibrand River.</p><p> Two sheds and farm equipment were destroyed.</p><p> Fire destroyed about 300ha of a pine plantation at Mt Lonarch, in central Victoria, and an early-morning blaze</p><p>in the Yarra State Forest near Wesburn, northeast of</p><p>Melbourne, destroyed 50ha</p><p>of bushland.</p><p> CFA firefighters contained the fire in seven hours.</p><p> Fifty firefighters struggled to contain a blaze at Pheasant Creek, while wind reignited a fire that had been smouldering for weeks at a mulch factory in Dandenong South.</p><p> Firefighters were aided by a cool change that drifted across the state yesterday morning.</p><p> CFA spokesman John Tindall said people in fire-prone areas must immediately clean up potential fire hazards near their homes and plan what to do in the event of fire.</p><p> "The conditions . . . pushed us into summer six weeks early," Mr Tindall said.</p><p> "Unless we get rain in spring and early summer we can expect more of these days. Without rain we will have a (fire season) of five to six months."</p><p> At Melbourne airport yesterday, 14 Victorian firefighters were welcomed home after six weeks fighting forest fires in the US.</p><p> Department of Natural Resources and Environment, Parks Victoria and CFA firefighters helped contain a 202,000ha forest fire in the Siskiyou National Forest at Gold Beach, Oregon. It caused about $280 million damage.</p><p> Environment Minister Sherryl Garbutt said US authorities had commended the Victorian firefighters for their "outstanding professionalism".</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5D83-Y581-JD6R-T16N-00000-00What I learned from debating science with trolls2014-08-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisWhat I learned from debating science with trollsMichael Brown

Maurice Newman's recent contribution to global warming commentary harnesses some of the favourite tactics of internet cranks, who rely on distorted expert opinion and broken logic.

The Conversation

I often like to discuss science online and I’m also rather partial to topics that promote lively discussion, such as , and (perhaps surprisingly) the . This inevitably brings out the .

“Don’t feed the trolls” is sound advice, but I’ve ignored it on occasion – including on The Conversation and Twitter – and I’ve been rewarded. Not that I’ve changed the minds of any trolls, nor have I expected to.

But I have received an education in the tactics many trolls use. These tactics are common not just to trolls but to bloggers, journalists and politicians who attack science, from climate to cancer research.

Some techniques are comically simple. Emotionally charged, yet evidence-free, accusations of scams, fraud and cover-ups are common. While they mostly lack credibility, such accusations may be effective at polarising debate and reducing understanding.

And I wish I had a dollar each time a scientifically incompetent ideologue claimed . The chairman of the Prime Minister’s Business Advisory Council, Maurice Newman, trotted out that old chestnut in The Australianlast week. Australia’s Chief Scientist, Ian Chubb, was less than impressed by Newman’s use of that tactic.

Unfortunately there are too many tactics to discuss in just one article (sorry Gish Gallop and ), so I will focus on just a few that I’ve encountered online and in the media recently.

‘Experts’

Internet trolls know who their experts are. There are thousands of professors scattered across academia, so it isn’t surprising that a few contrarians can be found. In online discussions I’ve been told of the contrarian views of “respected” professors from Harvard, MIT and Princeton.

Back in The Conversation’s early days I even copped abuse for not being at Princeton by someone who was clearly unfamiliar with both science and my . It was a useful lesson that vitriol is often disconnected from knowledge and expertise.

At times expert opinion is totally misrepresented, often with remarkable confidence.

Responding to one of my Conversation articles, The Australian Financial Review’s the findings of CSIRO’s John Church on sea levels.

Even after I that Lawson had the science wrong, Lawson .

Such distortions aren’t limited to online debates. In The Australian, Maurice Newman warned about imminent global cooling and cited Professor Mike Lockwood’s research as evidence.

But Lockwood himself stated last year that solar variability this century may reduce warming by:

...between 0.06 and 0.1 degrees Celsius, a very small fraction of the warming we’re due to experience as a result of human activity.

Newman’s claims were debunked, by his expert, before he even wrote his article.

Sometimes experts are quoted correctly, but they happen to disagree with the vast majority of their equally qualified (or more qualified) colleagues. How do the scientifically illiterate select this minority of experts?

I’ve asked trolls this question a few times and, funnily enough, they cannot provide good answers. To be blunt, they are choosing experts based on agreeable conclusions rather than scientific rigour, and this problem extends well beyond online debates.

Earlier this month, Senator Eric Abetz controversially seemed to link abortions with breast cancer on Channel Ten’s The Project.

While Abetz distanced himself from these claims, his media statement doesn’t dispute them and talks up the expertise of Dr Angela Lanfranchi, who does link abortions with breast cancer.

Abetz does not have expertise in medical research, so why did he give Dr Lanfranchi’s views similar or more weight than those of most doctors, including the Australian Medical Association’s president , who say there is no clear link between abortion and breast cancer?

If Abetz cannot evaluate the medical research data and methods, is his choice largely based on Dr Lanfranchi’s conclusions? Why won’t he accept the views of most medical professionals, who can evaluate the relevant evidence?

Abetz may be doctor shopping, not for a desired diagnosis or drug, but for an desired expert opinion. And just as doctor shopping can result in the wrong diagnosis, doctor shopping for opinions gives you misleading conclusions.

Broken logic

Often attacks on science employ logic so flawed that it would be laughable in everyday life. If I said my car was blue, and thus no cars are red, you would be unimpressed. And yet when non-experts discuss science, such flawed logic is often employed.

Carbon dioxide emissions are leading to rapid climate change now, and gradual natural climate change has also taken place over aeons. There’s no reason for natural and anthropogenic climate change to be mutually exclusive, and yet climate change deniers frequently use natural climate change in an attempt to disprove anthropogenic global warming.

Figure 1: Global temperatures (measured by Marcott et al. in dark blue, and HadCRUT4 in red) have changed as a result of both natural and anthropogenic climate change. There has been a dramatic rise in global temperatures over the past century. 

Source: Michael Brown

Unfortunately our Prime Minister, Tony Abbott, employed similar broken logic after the 2013 bushfires:

"Australia has had fires and floods since the beginning of time. We’ve had much bigger floods and fires than the ones we’ve recently experienced. You can hardly say they were the result of anthropic [sic] global warming."

Bushfires are a natural part of the Australian environment but that does not exclude climate change altering the frequency and intensity of those fires. Indeed, the Forest Fire Danger Index has been increasing across Australia since the 1970s.

Why the Prime Minister would employ such flawed logic, and contradict scientific research, is puzzling.

Galileo

The Italian scientist and astronomer Galileo Galilei was infamously persecuted by the politically powerful Catholic Church because of his promotion of the sun-centred solar system.

While Galileo suffered house arrest, his views ultimately triumphed because they were supported by observation, while the Church’s stance relied on theology.

The Galileo Gambit is a debating technique that perverts this history to defend nonsense. Criticisms by the vast majority of scientists are equated with the opinions of 17th century clergy, while a minority promoting pseudoscience are equated with Galileo.

Ironically, the Galileo Gambit is often employed by those who have no scientific expertise and strong ideological reasons for attacking science. And its use isn’t restricted to online debates.

Bizarrely, even the politically powerful and well connected are partial to the Galileo Gambit. Maurice Newman (once again) rejects the consensus view of climate scientists and, when questioned on his rejection of the science, his (perhaps predictable)   response was:

"Well, Galileo was virtually on his own."

Newman’s use of a tactic of trolls and cranks is worthy of criticism. The triumph of Galileo’s views were a result of his capacity to develop scientific ideas and test them via observation. Newman, and many of those who attack science, notably lack this ability.

Michael J. I. Brown is an observational astronomer, ARC Future Fellow and senior lecturer at Monash University.

Michael J. I. Brown receives research funding from the Australian Research Council and Monash University.
