urn:contentItem:4BVK-8260-01W7-603W-00000-00<published>2004-03-05T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:56Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 2</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Helicopters called in for Otway blaze;<br/>Aerial attack targets blaze</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>JENNY SHAND</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE lumbering Ericsson Air Crane had a sting in its tail and the Otways fire in its sights.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The huge helicopter dumped its load of water in a deluge over the burning forest about 10 kilometres northwest of Lorne. It hit its target, circled the smoke and headed off again.</p><p>The sky crane, holding up to 9000 litres and the largest fire-fighting aircraft on contract, was part of a three-strong aerial assault that blitzed the Benwerrin blaze from above as ground crews fought the battle below.</p><p> White plumes of smoke climbed from the state forest's canopy beside Mt Sabine Road, slipstreaming coastward on a north-westerly wind mid-afternoon.</p><p> The haze of smoke and heat washed the Otways with a dull coat, its ridges disappearing into the horizon like a rumpled green blanket.</p><p> People in the Otways know the scent of smoke. They've been assaulted by it, and by searing heat, before. On Ash Wednesday in '83 and at other times.</p><p> And authorities wasted no time yesterday to rush resources to the fire before it could grow in stature on the total fire ban day.</p><p> Two medium-sized helitak helicopters circled the smoke several times before starting their own assault. They teamed with the air crane to help quell the fire, looking like underfed insects next to the mighty Ericsson. But they did the job, their waterfalls shining in a silver curtain as they hurled towards the ground.</p><p> A red and white helicopter patrolled the sky, directing the water-bomber crews towards their target.</p><p> The two-pronged attack -- ground and air -- turned the tide and the smoke plumes soon shrunk to thin wisps of white, like an old man's combover.</p><p> A house nestled in clearing less than a kilometre from the two-hectare fire. Other houses were dotted along Mt Sabine Road, pockets of private land vulnerable in the face of a forest fire. While their occupants might have had the smell of smoke in their nostrils, they were safe. The fire did not threaten any private property.</p><p> As the afternoon crept on and the fire shut down, the helicopters left. The air crane departed first, called away to another fire. Then the medium helicopters flew off, and the Otway sky was left cleaned, clear of all but a drift of smoke.</p><p> fire  watch</p><p>LORNE</p><p>Fire in Mt Sabine Road, Erskine Falls Road area behind Lorne.</p><p>Possibly started by fallen power lines.</p><p>DSE and CFA crews hit the fire with two bulldozers, two helitankers and a sky crane.</p><p>Burned about two hectares.</p><p>Fire described as moderate but with significant spotting.</p><p>No property or stock lost.</p><p>MURGHEBOLUC</p><p>Fire started on Hamilton Highway following motor vehicle accident.</p><p>Small area burned, quickly controlled by local units.</p><p>About nine units attended.</p><p>But an evening wind change temporarily re-ignited the blaze with several crews returning to extinguish it.</p><p>BIRREGURRA</p><p>Police are investigating the cause of a three-hectare blaze that started on the side of the road. Five units from three brigades attended the fire. Brought under control in 10 minutes.</p><p>PITFIELD</p><p>A Geelong strike team helps fight a 510-hectare fire at Pitfield, southwest of Ballarat.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P8H-NNC0-TXN5-S01G-00000-00(Environment Watch)1995-06-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisNEWSEnvironment WatchPg. 19(Environment Watch)Nature Report

Earthquakes.

Indonesia's Flores Island was rocked by several large tremors, the strongest of which wrecked more than 100 homes and injured two people.

In Peru, a correspondent for the Agence France Presse news agency was killed in Lima when a tremor unleashed a rockslide that sent a boulder crashing through the window of his car.

Earth movements were also felt in the Kobe, Japan, aftershock zone, Crete, Belgium, Alaska and South California.

Drought.

Farmers in China's north-west Gansu province have given up any hope of a summer harvest as their crops withered under the region's worst drought in 60 years. The China Daily reported that more than 70 per cent of the poverty-stricken province's farmlands have been affected by the extended dry spell.

The Southern African Development Community (SADC) appealed to the international community for $90.7 million in emergency food aid to help avert starvation in Lesotho, Malawi, Swaziland, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

Wildfires.

Forest fires that have scarred many parts of northern and western Canada in recent weeks spread into Ontario as temperatures reached record high levels. With blazes still roaring in British Columbia, Manitoba and Saskatchewan, the only relief was in Alberta where rain dampened some blazes. Petroleum waste may be fuelling a two-week-old Mexican forest fire.

Monsoon.

Unrelenting heat that has killed hundreds across the Indian subcontinent was broken by cloudbursts and massive flooding. As many as two million people may have been marooned by high waters in Bangladesh. In Nepal, landslides and flash floods killed 60 people in two weeks of unusually heavy downpours. China's Guangdong province was hit with severe flooding.

Amazon poaching.

More than 12 million exotic animals a year are illegally trapped in Brazil's Amazon rainforest and sold, says the World Wide Fund for Nature. Of those captured, only 10 per cent make it to the black market and stores alive, where they are sold.

Hurricane season.

Adolph, the season's first hurricane in the eastern Pacific, formed several weeks later than has been the average in recent years, briefly threatening the Mexican coast near Mazatlan.

Metro refuge.

French insect lovers want parts of the Paris Metro to be declared a nature reserve, fearing the subway is getting too clean for rare colonies of crickets that chirp in the warm, dark tunnels. While most commuters welcome efforts to rid the Metro of pests, one insect special-interest group wants protective measures for the crickets, whose buzzing is a symbol of good fortune in French folklore.

urn:contentItem:4P8B-H110-TXN5-R1DC-00000-00Arson behind half of fires2000-09-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 2Arson behind half of firesPhilip Cornford, and Joseph Kerr

Tinder-dry conditions across most of NSW have brought out a plague of arsonists and left pollution levels high, with the Rural Fire Service saying many of the 65 bushfires burning along coastal areas were intentionally started.

"We have evidence that at least 50 per cent of the fires were deliberately lit," an RFS spokesman, Mr John Winter, said yesterday as more than 700 firefighters battled forest fires.

"At Nambucca Heads, 11 fires were lit along a fire trail within an hour, eventually combining into one big fire. At Lake Macquarie, there were 10 deliberately lit ignition points for a fire."

All 65 fires, almost all of them on the northern coastal areas between Newcastle and Taree, were brought under control or extinguished yesterday as temperatures and winds dropped. No houses were under threat.

Sydney's hot, dry spell has also contributed to the haze over the city, with two readings in the top pollution band this week..

The Environmental Protection Authority has extended its "no burn" order, as Sydney suffers temperatures two degrees higher than normal, humidity of 40 per cent rather than the usual 50 per cent, and only 9.2mm of rainfall for the month.

"There has been a lot of smoke from the bushfires around Sydney," an EPA spokeswoman, Ms Lisa Corbyn, said. "At the same time, the still weather [Tuesday night] and earlier [yesterday] meant the smoke was hanging around."

With conditions improving, the RFS commissioner, Mr Phil Koperberg, lifted the 24-hour total fire ban, but warned that the fire danger remained high.

Three big forest fires two covering 5,000 hectares and one 2,500 hectares were burning in the Grafton area. A 2,500-hectare fire was burning near Tamworth.

In the metropolitan area, smoke from a forest fire at Holsworthy and a grass fire at Penrith hazed the city and its western outskirts.

Mr Winter said a dry winter and heavy frosts had left big areas of highly flammable grass and forest floor.

Apart from those started by arsonists, about 40per cent of fires were caused by human error and 10per cent by natural causes such as lightning strikes, he said.

"Unextinguished cigarettes are the biggest cause of human-error fires," he said. "But a lot of people are careless when it comes to parking their cars on dry grass, which can be ignited by their exhausts when they leave."

Mr Winter appealed to the public to report any suspicious activities immediately.

"Arson is a crime which puts lives and property at risk," he said. "We would also like people to be more thoughtful about their behaviour and more forthright about reporting fires they might have accidentally started. We are not interested in blaming anyone, but we want to get to the fires as quickly as we can."

Illus: Smoke haze hovers over the Homebush area, behind and to the right of the Anzac Bridge. Photo: Anita Jones.

Pg. 7</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Linton volunteer scorns fire guide</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Kristine Gough</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A FIREFIGHTERS training guide describing the forest fire that killed five men at Linton two years ago contained inaccurate "crap", a Country Fire Authority volunteer told an inquest into the deaths yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Craig McInnes told the Linton fire inquest the case study was like a trashy tabloid newspaper: full of crap but reading it made people feel good.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "I'd put the Linton report in the same category," he said.</p><p>Five Geelong-based volunteers died in December 1998 when their empty water tanker was incinerated after a sudden wind change during the firefight near Linton, south-west of Ballarat.</p><p> The case study of the fire was distributed last year to all CFA brigades in Victoria and formed part of training in how to reduce the risk of entrapment in wildfires.</p><p> Mr McInnes said the report, jointly compiled by by the CFA and Victoria's Department of Natural Resources, contained a number of inaccuracies.</p><p> The report described winds on the day as "light", but also contained wind speed figures of up to 44kmh.</p><p> "That's a hell of a light breeze," Mr McInnes said.</p><p> The volunteer, with 20 years' experience, broke down when he disputed the report's claim that there were 27 tankers lined up in the path of the fire at one point, saying his tanker was the only one there when the fire passed over.</p><p> "There was me," he said.</p><p> Mr McInnes, part of a group of tankers from the Linton area putting out spot fires near the main firefront, was forced to drive his Snake Valley tanker through the flames as the fire advanced down a hill.</p><p> He said that despite the report's flaws, he would like to see all of its recommendations implemented.</p><p> "Because we do a hell of a lot of work, we spend a lot of time, we spend a lot of money, and I'd like to come home every time," he said, fighting back tears.</p><p> The report recommends wide-ranging reviews of CFA training, procedures and equipment.</p><p> Under cross-examination by John Langmead, for the Department of Natural Resources, Mr McInnes rejected suggestions his tanker, stationed along a road near the head of the fire, was in a dangerous position.</p><p> "If I shouldn't have been there, I wouldn't have been there," he said.</p><p> "I don't get paid for it. It makes me wonder even why I do it," he said.</p><p> State Coroner Graeme Johnstone later expressed hope that Mr McInnes would continue to serve with the CFA.</p><p> "(I think) everyone in court would take the view that you're the type that should be involved in firefighting," Mr Johnstone said.</p><p> In a written statement, Mr McInnes was critical of the of co-operation between different organisational levels within the CFA.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P85-1CN0-TXN5-R1TC-00000-00CINE FILE1998-03-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESArtsPg. 15CINE FILEYOUR GUIDE TO THE LATEST FILM RELEASESPaul Bymes, Sandra Hall

GOOD WILL HUNTING

What it does, it does very well, but what it does isn't much. It's the year's first inspirational film, the story of a genius born on the wrong side of the tracks. Will Hunting (Damon) is a kind of enfant sauvage from the mean Irish streets of south Boston. He's an orphan, and he and his pals love baseball, girls and fighting turf wars with the local Italian boys. Will's in denial of what he is, for one thing: he refuses to act like a genius, even though he knows he probably is one. After what seems an eternity of clues, he is noticed by Professor Gerald Lambeau and the plot to civilise Will Hunting begins. Lambeau rescues Will from the gutter and hands him over to a famous therapist called Sean McGuire (Robin Williams). Most of this is predictable - fireworks, bad behaviour, tough love - and it gets progressively more maudlin, but the film does have one surprising grace note, and that's the casting of Minnie Driver as Skylar, an English girl studying at Harvard. Driver steals Will's heart and the movie itself. - Paul Byrnes

FIRESTORM

FORMER pro football star Howie Long quickly becomes part of the scenery in his screen debut - an action adventure about a gang of firefighters in the Wyoming state forests. With a neck like a tree trunk, a face seemingly chiselled out of pine and an acting style to match, he could beat a forest fire to death, if he didn't first bore it into submission. Howie and his team are "smokejumpers" - firefighters who parachute into burning forests. Writer Soth isn't strong on logic. Nor does he trust the fearsomeness of the fire to keep the plot revved up. As a result, he throws in a gang of escaped convicts, led by William Forsythe, a good actor when the circumstances are right, but completely baffled by his role here. He plays a sort of paste-up of villains gone by. While Forsythe hams it up, Howie doesn't act at all, and Scott Glenn, who actually manages a performance, has nowhere to take it, as the director Semler pumps up the music and lays on the bathos. - Sandra Hall

* Hurricane Streets

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: INDONESIA SET FOR REPEAT OF LAST YEAR'S FIRE DISASTER</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Karen Polglaze, South East Asia Correspondent</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA, March 5 AAP - Indonesia looks increasingly set for a repeat of last year's forest fire catastrophe with new fires reported on the island of Sumatra.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Parts of East Kalimantan, in the Indonesian part of Borneo island, are still ablaze weeks after igniting in the drought-stricken province, contaminating water supplies and destroying thousands of hectares of national park.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Local government officials in Aceh in the northern part of Sumatra reported this week that 30 hectares of protected forest was alight and that no rain had been experienced there for more than a month.</p><p>A further 60 hotspots were reported in Riau, central Sumatra, a province badly hit by fires last year.</p><p> A nightmarish repeat of the haze which forced airport closures, disrupted sea traffic and caused health problems for millions of Indonesians and their neighbours in Malaysia and Singapore is reportedly occuring in East Kalimantan.</p><p> Visibility was down to less than a kilometre in the cities of Samarinda and Bailikpapan, although airports there remained open.</p><p> "We are worried about the traffic situation," local government official Murdiyansah told Associated Press.</p><p> "Visibility is very poor on the roads."</p><p>East Kalimantan's fires have possibly caused the level of acidity in the Barito River to reach levels beyond human tolerance, according to South Kalimantan local waterworks official Sugiyarto.</p><p> The fires were burning trees down to their roots, producing high concentrations of acid, making the water unfit to drink and threatening the plankton on which freshwater fish survive.</p><p> "Water acidity at the Barito and Martapura Rivers have reached from pH2.5 to pH3, which are beyond the tolerable limit of pH5," Sugiyarto told official newsagency Antara.</p><p> Other rivers in Kalimantan were also affected.</p><p>East Kalimantan in particular has received little rain since falls in December and officials estimate that more than 20,000 hectares have been burned since January.</p><p> The Indonesian government is carrying out cloud seeding in the hope of bringing rain to the drought-stricken province.</p><p> Meanwhile, people cut down young trees to beat the flames that threaten their houses and crops.</p><p> Plantation companies using fire as a cheap but illegal way to clear land for planting timber and oil palms have been blamed for a large part of the problem.</p><p> Land clearance for transmigration has also been held responsible, as have traditional slash and burn farmers.</p><p> Fires last year sent a blanket of haze across a significant part of South-East Asia, creating air pollution levels so high a 10-day state of emergency was declared in the Malaysian state of Sarawak on Borneo Island.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>MANILA, Feb 17 Asia Pulse - A multi-faceted marketing and</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MANILA, Feb 17 Asia Pulse - A multi-faceted marketing and communications initiative to encourage international travel to the Pacific Region and Asia in general is now being implemented by the Pacific Asia Travel Association (PATA).</p><p nitf:lede="true">PATA will hold its 47th Annual Conference at the Philippine International Convention Centre (PICC) from March 29 to April 2.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Joseph McInerney, the new PATA chief executive, calls the initiative the "Action Plan".</p><p>The plan is a series of short-term, tactical programs designed to assist PATA member destinations adversely affected by the continuing currency devaluation and the stock market upheaval.</p><p> The plan also aims to address the damage wrought to the Southeast Asian region's travel and tourism industry by last year's Indonesian forest fire pollution.</p><p> The first set of open forum meetings with tourism and business leaders took place in December last year in Jakarta and Bali, Indonesia; Singapore; Kuala Lumpur; Bangkok; Macau and Hong Kong.</p><p> Similar meetings are scheduled during the first half of this year in East Asia, Northeast Asia, South Asia and the South Pacific.</p><p> "The action plan is the first phase of the effort. During the visits, we seek input from the membership on existing programs and suggestions for other areas in which PATA can provide assistance," Mclnerney said.</p><p> Initial elements of the plan include the following:</p><p> - Effective with the Dec. 1, 1997 edition of "What's New in the Pacific Asia," PATA is placing special emphasis on bargains and promotions being offered by PATA members.</p><p>"What's New" is distributed to PATA's international media mailing list and is also posted online for consumers at <url normalizedValue="http://www.pata.org">www.pata.org</url> under "Travel News."</p><p> - The listing of special bargains and promotions will also be provided to all 79 PATA Chapters for distribution to member travel agents.</p><p> - Travel agent workshops will be organised in Australia and New Zealand during the first half of 1998 to promote travel to Asia. Coupled with the sessions will be media events for consumer and trade reporters.</p><p> - From October 1997, PATA will have conducted five major working media trips by May 1998, with North American and European journalists to help promote travel to the region.</p><p> Participating destinations include Vietnam, India, Hong Kong, Papua New Guinea and Sarawak, Malaysia. In addition, a working trip to the South Pacific will be organised later this year.</p><p> - PATA and Time Magazine are collaborating to offer Communications workshops throughout the region. The two-day workshops are designed to help mid-level public relations employees improve their media relations skills.</p><p> - In conjunction with the Communications Workshops, the host destination will have the opportunity to hold a single-day media or product promotion workshop.</p><p> (PNA)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3S1W-9M80-0048-T27N-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="474"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Firestorms ride wind</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FIRESTORMS roared down the northern corridor yesterday afternoon destroying two homes and other buildings in a day when nature turned on the Gold Coast.</p><p nitf:lede="true">   One home was lost in Jenkins Court, Coomera, and another in Fairview Drive, Willow Vale.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Late last night Rural District Inspector Bernard Trembath said conditions were beginning to ease, however the situation was still critical.</p><p> "Conditions have been kind to us this evening," he said.</p><p>   "The winds have dropped and the weather has cooled off which has enabled us to begin back-burning operations and other strategic plans.</p><p>   "Most of the fires are not yet under control but we are making inroads."</p><p>   As firefighters continued to battle last night, Energex crews were working feverishly to restore power to 11,000 homes in 19 suburbs across the Coast.</p><p>   Winds gusting between 80km/h and 100km/h during the day brought down powerlines and trees, threw debris across lines and caused lines to arc together.</p><p>   An Energex spokeswoman said 50 per cent of power had been restored by 6pm and crews were confident all would be restored last night.</p><p>   Over 2000 homes in Andrews, Burleigh Heads and Currumbin Valley were hit, after the roaring westerlies brought down a major 30,000-volt line in Reedy Creek Road just before 11am.</p><p>   Energex crews were still working to restore that line last night.</p><p>   The major fires were in Upper Coomera, which was under control late yesterday afternoon, and a large forest fire burning on two fronts at Willow Vale, which was still burning last night.</p><p>  The blaze in Upper Coomera, which is believed to have started from powerlines arcing together shortly after 1pm, centred around Jenkins Court and Old Coach Road.</p><p>   Firefighters and police evacuated residents from Jenkins Court and the west side of Old Coach Road by mid-afternoon.    Queensland Fire and Rescue Service area director Bruce Byatt said the area was very steep and inaccessible.</p><p>   "People's driveways are half a kilometre long and we had little water here," he said. "That made it very hard."</p><p>   He said there were about 50 firefighters at the Upper Coomera blaze with four urban and five rural units.</p><p>   The Willow Vale fire was burning on two fronts last night, one around Fern Hill Drive and the second at Fairview Drive.</p><p>   District inspector Trembath said the fire was a ground fire rather than one jumping from ridge to ridge. He said the cause was not yet known.</p><p>  Gold Coast Rural Fire Brigades group captain Len Jeavons said, apart from the the two main fronts, his volunteers were also fighting small fires at Currumbin Valley, Tallebudgera, Mudgeeraba and Wongawallan.</p><p>   "These winds have wreaked havoc and this day will be remembered for a while," he said.</p><p>   QFRS fire officers barely stopped all day, fighting numerous grass fires along the M1 verges and spot fires around fallen powerlines.</p><p>   "It's the busiest day we've had in ages," said Southport station officer Gordon Hemphrey.</p><p>   Police were also needed to escort Labrador Primary School children around live, fallen powerlines in Turpin Road and near Gilston Primary School yesterday after school.</p><p>   An Energex spokeswoman said the following suburbs lost power for at least two hours yesterday:</p><p>   Andrews, Burleigh Heads, Currumbin Valley, Tallebudgera, Nerang, Hope Island, Oxenford, Sanctuary Cove, Bonogin, Beenleigh, Mudgeeraba, Neranwood, Numinbah Valley, Natural Bridge, Binna Burra, Springbrook, Clagiraba, Jacobs Well and Rocky Point.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:458X-7B70-0197-83RJ-00000-00<published>1998-01-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:56Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FULLPAGE, LOCAL; Pg. 5</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Kids cry for bush heroes  / TRAIL OF TRAGEDY AS VOLUNTEERS BATTLE BLAZES ACROSS THE STATE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>SARAH HARRIS</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE children of a critically injured bush fire fighter yesterday called for greater recognition of the heroism of ordinary people who risked their lives for a "special kind of love". Gale Pritchett and her husband Frank are battling for their lives after being trapped fighting a horror New Year's blaze in the Southern Highlands.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Mrs Pritchett's daughter Kim, 19, and 21-year-old son Simon issued an impassioned plea for support for the Rural Fire Service both in thought and in deed.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>More young people should put down their "Nintendo games"</p><p>and join the brigade while governments should recognise firefighters' efforts with "some small token", they said.</p><p> It was Gale Pritchett's dedication to the Southern Highlands hamlet of Wingello which saw her respond to a New Year's Day fire call together with husband Frank.</p><p> And it is this same sense of society which, her children say, makes both of them heroic.</p><p>Gale's son Simon, 21, explained: "It is a different type of love.</p><p>They risked their lives.</p><p> "Every time that beeper goes off you don't know if you are going to come back . . . it's the risk that you take."  Like their mother, stepfather and father, Kim and Simon are also members of the bush fire brigade, and display a remarkable stoicism in their suffering.</p><p> Today Frank and Gale Pritchett lie critically injured in the intensive care wards of hospitals half a city from one another.</p><p> They are the survivors of a forest fire trap which killed one of their closest mates, David Quinlivan, and seriously injured five of their Wingello Rural Fire Service Brigade colleagues.</p><p> Since New Year's Day Kim and Simon have been commuting from their mother's bedside in the intensive care unit of Royal North Shore to their stepfather's, at Westmead.</p><p> "I keep telling mum: 'come on, hurry up and get just a little bit better and then you can both be together'," Kim says.</p><p> "She can't respond verbally at the moment, but we know that she can hear us."  Gale's only son Simon tells stories about his nine-month-old daughter Jacquelyn -a much loved first grandchild.</p><p> "Mum has so much time for her and she loves Frank -loves to tickle his beard."  The couple, who have been married barely a year, met at a bush fire brigade function.</p><p> Both long-time bush fire brigade members, they were under no illusions about the risks of living in the area.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P78-17M0-TXN5-S3B2-00000-00Cole comfort2003-11-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisAGENDAPg. 24Cole comfortPREVIEW - Arts - MusicSophie Best

Lloyd Cole used to be uptight. Now the singer-songwriter is just bleak, he tells Sophie Best.

When Lloyd Cole and his band the Commotions landed in Australia for their 1986 tour, they were ushered into the most expensive hotel they'd ever seen. Marvelling at the luxury of their suite, the band members dialled the singer's room to compare notes. Cole's room was even bigger, and he was mortified. "I was embarrassed," he says, "so I asked to be moved."

"In retrospect," he says in his charmingly plummy, English-gentleman voice, "I should have taken it. After all, we weren't paying for it! But I was embarrassed to be the leader of the band, and that saddens me. I should have enjoyed it."

Cole didn't know it then, but the band had already peaked. Their debut album Rattlesnakes yielded three UK hits (the title track, plus Perfect Skin and Forest Fire), but that chart success was never to be repeated. Nor were they to play to crowds of 25,000 again, as they did in Sydney that night.

Not long after returning to England, Cole disbanded the group. "Once I realised I could do things on my own, I had this great joie de vivre. I wish I could have had that feeling when the band was together, but we were very uptight."

Behind their front as thinking women's heart-throbs, Cole says they were a miserable bunch. "We were afraid of offending each other, afraid of doing something that might be perceived as politically incorrect, afraid of having fun. Thank heavens we made decent records."

Cole moved to New York to pursue a solo career. "I had great fun being a solo artist," he says, "trying to be the David Bowie of my generation, and finding out quickly that I wasn't."

At the age of 42 and with his fifth solo release, Music in a Foreign Language, on the shelves, Cole says he'd now rather be Leonard Cohen. "Without becoming a Buddhist monk, or sacrificing my family for my art," he qualifies. "I want to make quiet songs for people who want to hear quiet music."

The songs on Music in a Foreign Language are indeed quiet - sombre, subdued, and quite often bleak. "I'm not trying to negate the beauty of life, the love and joy that I have," insists Cole, who now lives in rural Massachusetts with his wife and two children. "This group of songs just happens to be the bleakest I've ever done."

Cole has been exploring the mid-life yearning for escape. "You find yourself in status quo situations," he explains, "and sometimes you want to tear the whole thing up. You drive your car, seven days a week, and sometimes you just want the next truck to hit you."

Cole puts his family first, and is unconcerned as to how long his songwriting career might last. "If I wake up one day, and my creativity's gone, and I'm not writing songs anymore, that's fine," he says.

"In fact it's a bit of a pain, driving your car with this bloody song going round in your head," he adds playfully. "So I do rather look forward to when that's not the case."

Lloyd Cole plays the Forum Dec 4. Tel: 9299 9700

urn:contentItem:4P8H-NVW0-TXN5-S1HM-00000-00Fires a threat to water quality1997-12-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 8Fires a threat to water qualityFERGUS SHIEL

Summer bushfires could threaten the quality and volume of Melbourne's water supply, according to the chief fire officer with the Department of Natural Resources and Environment, Mr Gary Morgan.

Not since 1939 had fire posed such a threat to the water supply, he said.

Mr Morgan said it was almost 60 years since the mountain ash forests bordering the four main reservoirs - Thomson, Upper Yarra, O'Shannassy and Maroondah - had been consumed by fire, but there was a risk it could happen again this year.

"Mountain ash forests burn less frequently because they grow in high-rainfall areas," he said.

"(It is) in years like this and like 1939, when the state is tinder dry, that they really burn."

Mr Morgan said the mountain ash forests were "nature's own filtering system" and they helped to keep Melbourne's water clean.

"The problem that arises with fire is that if it goes right through . . . there's no natural filter and the rains that come will carry a lot of sediment into the streams and they'll carry charcoal," he said.

Melbourne Water's general manager, Mr Brian Bayley, said bushfires were a perennial concern but he was confident fires would not harm Melbourne's water quality.

"Our system provides for 30 to 40 days' retention of water, which gives it a long time to purify," he said.

He said the system did not require more dams or river augmentation but extensive forest destruction might force a rethink.

Both Mr Morgan and Mr Bayley said early fire detection systems and a sophisticated response capacity should reduce the summer fire threat.

Almost 200 forest fires have been recorded in Victoria since last Wednesday, with 97 on Wednesday alone.

Firefighters yesterday fought a 300-hectare blaze in coastal scrub at Golden Beach to the north of Lake Reeve, a 50-hectare forest fire at Bruthen, north of Bairnsdale, and another at Yambulla, north-east of Cann River. One hundred fires were being mopped up.

Mr Morgan said conditions in the bush were drier now than in the same period before the devastating 1983 Ash Wednesday bushfires.

Melbourne's reservoirs, following the driest 13 months on record, hold 75.3 per cent of their capacity, according to Melbourne Water.

It said the amount of water flowing into the four main reservoirs was last week up to 65.6 per cent below the long-term average.

Only 0.2 mm of rain fell in the water storage catchments last week.

Mr Bayley appealed to consumers to properly manage their water use.

urn:contentItem:49JV-RVM0-01S8-G15W-00000-00<published>1985-09-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:55Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>YOUR GUIDE TO SUMMER FLOWERS</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SEPTEMBER 15 Your guide to summer flowers BEFORE long spring flowers like stocks, poppies and pansies will have finished blooming and fresh summer plantings have to be considered.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Our summer is a long one with periods of weather that make gardening hard work. Plants and gardeners alike have to contend with heatwaves and cyclonic rains.</p><p nitf:lede="true">When choosing which summer flowers to plant, look for hardy varieties with a long flowering period so that several months of color will be obtained from one planting.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Ideal summer annuals need the capacity to endure all kinds of weather conditions and to cope with insect pests and flower freely in spite of temporary setbacks.</p><p>A lot of summer annuals meet these requirements. Others require a certain amount of coaxing.</p><p>Years ago I had an excellent crop of Giant Crego Asters in full bloom in mid-February. Then there was a week of heavy rain and wind.</p><p>The blooms, weighed down with water, were swept back and forth over muddy soil.</p><p>Now I advocate early planting of asters so that they flower before the end of the year when cyclonic con- ditions are less common than later in the summer.</p><p>There are fewer sum- mer flowers for cutting for vase use than there are among spring flowers; but that is offset by a group of annuals that provide garden color for long periods.</p><p>Some of the summer annuals can be raised very easily from seed.</p><p>Warm conditions favor rapid germination. Seed boxes or special seed beds are not always necessary.</p><p>Places in garden beds where the sown patch can be attended to easily will do nicely for marigolds, amaranthus, celosia, zinnia and cosmos, for instance. If the seeds are tiny, as for torenia and portulaca, seed boxes are advisable.</p><p>Annuals for cut flowers Asters are the best of the summer flowers for vase use. Once seedlings are established there is little to do beyond the usual maintenance but watch for insect damage in the heart of the plant. A caterpillar that establishes its home there causes some distortion of the leaves or even eats the growing point of the flower.</p><p>When preparing to flower the aster develops flower stalks from the central growing point. Because this insect pest is quite common, it is worthwhile to put Carbaryl, Dispel or Endopest into the hearts of the plants early in their life.</p><p>Several varieties of aster are sold. Colour Carpet is a dwarf type for edging beds and Giant Crego, Perfection and Totem Pole are sources of cut flowers.</p><p>Zinnias are available in many varieties, some of a stature and flower type that make them suitable for vases. Showman and Gold Medal are two in that category. Happy Talk, a variety with slightly curled and quilled petals, is a semi-dwarf offshoot from the variety Coquette.</p><p>The flower stalks of Happy Talk are relatively short, but the flowers can be used to good effect in certain sorts of vase. Some people regard the large-flowered zinnias as being too stiff and they might find Happy Talk more to their liking.</p><p>The African Marigold variety Jubilee is one with flower stalks that make it useful for cutting. Objections to the odor of the leaves of marigolds rule it out from consideration sometimes. Minimal trouble will be experienced if you avoid crushing the foliage.</p><p>The recently introduced Inca (from Thompson and Morgan) and African Queen (from Yates) are varieties with very large, fully double flowers.</p><p>Although short in the stalks, the flowers can be used effectively in certain kinds of container. For garden decoration they are a spectacular success.</p><p>Tall plants for garden color Amaranthus is the tallest of the summer annuals, providing a bright effect with its colored foliage. Its relative celosia makes its show with its colored inflorescences, that is, the total flowering parts.</p><p>Forest Fire is the variety to choose, the other celosias being short to medium in height.</p><p>Amaranthus plants should grow a metre or more high and, to ensure that, the soil should be enriched with organic matter and complete fertiliser before plants are set out.</p><p>Add supplementary fertiliser as they grow and ensure there is never any water shortage. Forest Fire celosias need similar treatment. These very colorful plants mix well with the tall varieties of zinnia.</p><p>Low to medium height Plants of limited height are used for edgings. Torenia (blue), and Zinnia linearis (Little Star) and Globe Amaranth (Little Buddy), portulaca and French Marigolds are all hardy and free-flowering. Little attention is needed once they are established, remembering of course that watering and weeding are essential, routine procedures.</p><p>The African Marigolds make an excellent show over many weeks. Cosmos should not be neglected. Perhaps they fell into disfavor when off-white and washed-out red were predominant colors.</p><p>Sunny Gold Cosmos, introduced last summer, has yellow, double flowers. My plants reached about 60cm high.</p><p>Mammoth, a single variety with rose and crimson flowers, can be even taller. Salvia (red), annual balsam (with red, white or pink flowers resembling small camellias) and petunia all do well in summer. Salvia should have spent flowers removed weekly and should never be allowed to run short of water. ]</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>PICS SHOW MARIGOLDS AND SUMMER ANNUALS</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:457Y-MHB0-0197-52TP-00000-00<published>1997-10-02T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:55Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 6</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Haze crisis flares as fires spread to Malaysia</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA: South-East Asia's air pollution crisis took a turn for the worse yesterday as forest fires broke out for the first time in Malaysia and spread in Indonesia just when rain and winds had eased the smoky haze over the region.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Firefighters were trying to contain a forest fire near tribal settlements in Malaysia's central Pahang State, but a water shortage was hampering efforts, officials and witnesses said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> In Indonesia, where forest fires have mainly raged on Sumatra and Borneo, new outbreaks were reported on Java, Sulawesi and Lombok near Bali.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>AFP, Reuters</p></bodyText></section><p>Stephen Lunn reports that the Australian Government yesterday pledged another $1 million toward aerial water bombing assistance to bring new spot fires under control.</p><p> Australian planes will be used to water bomb the toxic Indonesian fires, Alexander Downer said. Earlier this week the Foreign Minister committed $1 million in emergency relief for medical and health supplies to help locals cope with the hazardous smog pollution.</p><p> The crisis was poised yesterday to claim its first political casualty after Indonesian Forestry Minister Jamaluddin Suryohadikusumo took responsibility for the fires in the face of growing criticism of the Government's failure to mount an effective response.</p><p> In Amsterdam, Greenpeace urged Indonesia's President Suharto to help prevent new fires while the UN humanitarian affairs office in Jakarta said the fires were "out of control" and it was "unlikely that current firefighting operations will have a marked effect on extinguishing the fires". In Singapore, the Straits Times newspaper used a series of colour photographs to make the point the fires were no accident or act of nature.</p><p> The photos showed forests were being cleared to make way for plantations, with fire used to remove natural vegetation.</p><p>"The fires raging in Kalimantan and Sumatra appear to have been started deliberately to clear huge tracts of land on plantations as well as on small farms," the pro-government paper said.</p><p> It noted Indonesian timber barons had denied clearing by fire, and Indonesia's Co-ordinating Minister for People's Welfare said the fires were caused by the El Nino-induced drought. But the paper quoted an environmental expert saying El Nino did not start fires.</p><p> The report said the pictures, taken by the National University of Singapore Centre for Remote Imaging Sensing and Processing, could pinpoint the fires to within 10 to 20 metres. They were precise enough that "by just looking at the photographs, Indonesian authorities should be able to tell who owns a piece of land which has been cleared by fire, or from which plumes of smoke rise". "With these pictures, the fire-starters cannot escape. If the Indonesian authorities need help, we can give it to them," a centre director said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:7W2G-8HV1-2RG6-Y3JX-00000-00Royal commission urged to make protection of life its priority2009-07-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisThe World Today12:26 PM AESTABCSimon LauderRoyal commission urged to make protection of life its priority

PETER CAVE: The Royal Commission into the Victorian bushfires has heard suggestions from the counsel assisting the inquiry, on what can be done to stop another catastrophe. The commissioners are due to consider interim recommendations fairly soon, before the next fire season begins.

The senior counsel assisting, Jack Rush QC, has spent the morning outlining what he believes should be done, based on the last eight weeks of evidence. The head of the Country Fire Authority has also been singled out for some criticism.

Simon Lauder is at the royal commission in Melbourne and he joins us now. Simon, what are the main recommendations that Mr Rush wants to see made?

SIMON LAUDER: Well, as a whole Peter the suggestions amount to sweeping changes with the main objective to save lives and prevent a repeat of the disaster that saw hundreds of people trapped in their communities on Black Saturday.

In fact the senior counsel assisting the enquiry, Jack Rush QC, has recommended that the primacy of life become the main priority for fire agencies and that means a big focus on providing better warnings.

The counsel assisting says the warning tone which is used in cyclone areas should also be used to warn people in bushfire zones. It recommends towns also have the option of being warned by siren which may be operated by the local fire station.

A lot of witnesses at the royal commission have also asked that the public be told information which authorities used to judge the severity of predicted fires called "The Forest Fire Danger Index". The counsel assisting says that should happen.

And instead of having different fire agencies reporting different information at different times, the royal commission is being urged to propose a single website which people can access for information about what fires are doing in their area.

PETER CAVE: What other criticisms have there been of the way the authorities handled the situation on the day itself?

SIMON LAUDER: Well, the criticisms focussed on the heartbreaking revelations over the past few weeks that communities where dozens of people died had no public warning that the fire was coming or only about half an hour's notice and this is despite the fact that warnings had been drafted and were ready to go hours earlier.

It is due to a mix of communication breakdowns and a rigid sticking to the chain of command - people reluctant to go over someone's head and Jack Rush QC wants to see that change.

The commission's heard that no agency has a legal obligation to actually warn communities and the head of the Country Fire Authority, Russell Rees has given evidence that his role on the day was to provide general oversight but Jack Rush QC says one of the core responsibilities of the chief officer of the CFA is to warn communities of the risks the fires pose.

JACK RUSH: The coordination role as described by Mr Rees, we say is divorced from fundamental aspects of the statutory responsibility which was delegated on the day. The statutory obligations of the chief officer provide, we submit, for oversight in relation to fire prediction, provide for provision of information to communities, provide for the protection of life.

That is what is encompassed in the statutory role of the chief officer.

PETER CAVE: Jack Rush QC there.

How will the commissioners react to the suggestions, do you think?

SIMON LAUDER: Well, it is pretty much a take it or leave it scenario for them. They have got until the 17th of August to deliver an interim report so any recommendations can be put in place before the start of the next fire season. The commission will then resume and keep sitting well into 2010.

The counsel assisting has suggested that they actually set up a royal commission ombudsman to oversee the implementation of any recommendations and that would operate beyond the royal commission.

Senior counsel assisting the enquiry, Jack Rush QC this morning made it clear that his submission is only one element the commissioners will have to consider as they draft their interim report.

JACK RUSH: It needs to be understood that the submissions of counsel assisting are exactly that. The submissions represent the collective work and thoughts of counsel assisting at the bar table and the solicitors appointed to the royal commission. Our submissions as to suggested findings and recommendations, based on the evidence, carry no greater weight than the submissions put to you by any other represented party.

PETER CAVE: Jack Rush again and our reporter there Simon Lauder.

urn:contentItem:3SJF-S1M0-0045-50SX-00000-00<published>1997-10-01T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:55Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Part A; Page 4</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>AUSTRALIA 'SLOW' TO HELP INDONS</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>IAN MCPHEDRAN, FOREIGN AFFAIRS REPORTER</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The Federal Opposition has described the Government's response to Indonesia's forest-fire crisis, which includes a $1 million assistance package, as slow and indifferent.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Opposition environment spokesman Duncan Kerr accused the Government yesterday of being far too slow to realise the urgency of the crisis.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The fires have been burning for about four months, and intensely for six weeks, generating a pall of smog which has blanketed South-East Asia and caused several disasters, possibly including the crash of an Indonesian air liner in Sumatra with the loss of 234 lives.</p><p>Australians with health risks have been urged not to travel to Malaysia, Singapore, Indonesia or Brunei and some Australians have been offered government help to escape the extreme air pollution in Malaysia.</p><p>Mr Kerr said the Government should have offered immediate help to put the fires out and should have had a team of people on the ground now in Indonesia.</p><p>"It is plain common sense that if your neighbourhood is burning, the most immediate help you can give is pitch in and help put out the fire," he said.</p><p>"Whilst Mr Downer's offer of financial assistance will be of some use, it is not the most useful form of help and could send the wrong message." A government source said Australia was responding to specific calls for assistance from Indonesia and actual firefighters had not been requested.</p><p>Foreign Minister Alexander Downer, in New York for the United Nations General Assembly, announced the $1 million package after discussions with his Indonesian counterpart Ali Alatas.</p><p>The money will be used to provide medical and health supplies and other equipment such as water filters and face masks.</p><p>Mr Downer has also instructed Australia's aid agency, Aus- AID, to send two emergency response teams to Indonesia to assess the medical and fire-management needs.</p><p>A four-person medical team has been put together with the help of the Australian Red Cross and will leave for Indonesia at the weekend.</p><p>A five-member fire-management team from the Australian Fire Council Authority will leave on Friday and will be in the country for at least two weeks.</p><p>Both teams will begin reporting to the Government immediately.</p><p>Mr Downer said the Government was committed to working closely with Indonesian authorities to provide technical assistance in sustainable forestry and land management to avoid a recurrence of the crisis.</p><p>The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade warns people at risk, including those with respiratory disorders and pregnant women, not to travel to Malaysia, Indonesia or Brunei.</p><p>Garuda pilot was confused Page 9.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:57F9-RD71-JD3N-53NT-00000-00FIRE SUPPORT FROM AIR LONG OVERDUE2013-01-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 10FIRE SUPPORT FROM AIR LONG OVERDUEGEOFFREY LUCK

Every other country with serious wildfire risk has moved to prioritise aerial attack

ONCE again rural communities are being devastated by bushfires that the firefighting authorities are powerless to control. Yet the strategies employed reflect the resistance of entrenched bureaucracies to modern methods and the unwillingness of governments to fund them.

Over decades, a volunteer army has been deployed in what have nearly always been lost wars. Thousands of buildings have been destroyed -- some, like Mount Stromlo, national treasures; hundreds have died; there has been huge cost to government, insurance companies, communities and individuals. Yet every fire season, the generals commanding this army order their troops ``over the top'' in fruitless charges against the enemy -- crown fires in volatile eucalypt forest in inaccessible country.

The most devastating fires in Australia's history -- the Black Saturday fires in Victoria in February 2009 -- took 173 lives and cost millions in property damage, yet the focus of the royal commission came down to what individuals should or should not do when uncontrollable firestorms threaten. For example, Katharine Haynes of RMIT University, a researcher for Bushfire CRC, reasonably concluded from studying this and other fires over the past century that residents in risk-prone areas should prepare, stay and defend, or leave early.

What was not scrutinised was the basic concept of rural fire services built primarily on forces operating and controlled at ground level, hampered by untrafficable trails in inaccessible terrain and dependent for water supply on cumbersome, unmanoeuvrable vehicles. Aerial attack, the principal arm of forest and wildfire fighters in other countries, is still regarded, somewhat grudgingly, as an ancillary support service. For years, vested interests opposed the introduction of aircraft. Until that attitude changes, no government can claim to be taking bushfire-fighting seriously.

Greece may be bankrupt, but it supports a squadron of eight specialised water bombers. In the fire season they are controlled by an airborne observer who prioritises the firefronts and directs the attack.

Yet years after this strategy was proven, the NSW Rural Fire Service played down the role of aerial support. In the inquiry into the 2002 new year fires in the Shoalhaven district, the written submission of the RFS said: ``It is an understatement to suggest that aircraft and their reputed ability to extinguish fires is surrounded more by myth than realism.'' Former commissioner Phil Koperberg notoriously opposed aircraft. The lease of the S64 Sikorsky Aircranes had been delayed by bitter opposition on the grounds of cost, because aerial firefighting was always represented as an expensive addition to, instead of replacement for, the investment in the huge volunteer organisations.

In December 2006, as fires were burning in Tasmania and Victoria, I wrote to then prime minister John Howard and opposition leader Kevin Rudd, asking them to sponsor the establishment of a national firefighting squadron of water bombers. I nominated the specialist Canadian CL-415 (now designated Bombardier 415) used in 10 countries. When I lived in Italy, I helped set up a local bushfire brigade to deal with small grass and scrub fires, but when a serious fire in the pine and chestnut forest on the hills threatened, it was the Canadair water bombers that saved our village. Canadair operators in several northern hemisphere countries were willing to lease their aircraft to Australia during our bushfire season and their winter. Neither Howard nor Rudd replied to my letters.

The huge Sikorsky/Erickson S64 Aircranes that Australia leases from California may look impressive, but they represent gesture politics. What counts in water-bombing is turnaround time and load. Each of the giant helicopters can carry 9500 litres of water, but they take almost a minute to suck it up; they fly slowly to the fire at 100km/hour; and they can remain airborne for less than three hours before refuelling.

The Bombardier, a high-wing twin-turboprop aircraft, can scoop up its 6000 litres in 12 seconds, skimming any lake, river or the ocean at 130km/hour, fly to the fire at 300km/hour, dump and return for more while the Skycrane is still lumbering along with its first load. A single 415's ability to deliver 80,000 litres an hour within a 4km radius of its water supply means a squadron could have saved Mount Stromlo in 2003 -- as well as most of the 500 houses destroyed or damaged in the Canberra fires. The Victorian townships destroyed in 2009 were within operational reach of Lake Eildon, 60km away.

Both Los Angeles and San Diego have leased Bombardiers to fight their wildfires, but the US has so many mothballed aircraft that their place is increasingly taken by surplus Douglas DC-6 and DC-10 airliners, and ex-military Lockheed Hercules, Neptune and Orion planes. All are more effective and cost-effective than the light helicopters, which can lift only about 1000 litres but are commonly used in Australia because they are available and can attach a bucket without expensive conversion.

Every time bushfires take their toll in Australia, there are loud lamentations and even louder excuses. Politicians of all stripes hurry to sympathise with survivors. This is not to criticise them or decry the efforts of the ``orange army'' -- the thousands of volunteers who risk their lives at ground level -- but isn't it time for a complete rethink about bush firefighting? Every other country with serious seasonal wildfire risk has moved to make aerial attack the principal weapon against forest fire; only in Australia have vested interests rejected the strategy.

Shouldn't Australia be funding a modern aerial firefighting force as the principal arm, with the volunteer infantry used for what they do best -- containment, local protection and fuel reduction? Perhaps this time we might get a debate.

At $35 million each, a squadron of six Bombardier 415s would cost the commonwealth government only $210m.

This is peanuts compared with the recent waste in federal programs.

______________________________

>> Geoffrey Luck worked for the ABC for 26 years as a senior reporter and news editor.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Vic: The day bushfire tragedy hit</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>By Charisse Ede </nameText></person></author></nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>MELBOURNE, Jan 11</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">It has been three years and one month<br/>since five volunteer firemen died in the line of duty on a remote<br/>dirt track in central Victoria.<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">On December 2, 1998, Matthew Armstrong, 17, Jason Thomas, 25,<br/>Chris Evans, 27, Stuart Davidson, 28, and Garry Vredeveldt, 47,<br/>were among 200 firefighters who rallied to fight a forest fire<br/>between Geelong and Ballarat.<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">The Geelong West Country Fire Authority (CFA) firemen were an<br/>essentially urban crew, made up of a schoolboy, electrician, taxi<br/>driver and two public servants, with almost no training and<br/>experience in fighting bushfires.<br/></p><p>At 8.45pm, the crew ended up in Linton as part of a strike team,<br/>but suddenly found themselves with less than the recommended<br/>quarter of a tank of water.<br/></p><p>The crew's strike leader, fire officer Simon Scharf, directed<br/>them down a bush path towards a water reserve, without any<br/>knowledge of the wind change that was about to push the blaze back<br/>in the line of the firefighters.<br/></p><p>When the change did hit, two trucks were stranded on that dirt<br/>path; the inexperienced crew from Geelong West, and another, more<br/>experienced, crew from Geelong City.<br/></p><p>The second crew had more water reserves and used it to spray<br/>their truck as the flames leapt over them, but they could only<br/>watch in horror as the other truck erupted in a "wall of flame".<br/></p><p>It was several hours before the full extent of the tragedy was<br/>revealed, and the incident remains a turning point in the way the<br/>CFA handles wild fires.<br/></p><p>The inquest that followed became the second-longest inquest in<br/>Victoria's history, with more than 100 days of evidence and almost<br/>as many witnesses.<br/></p><p>The inquest, before Victorian Coroner Graeme Johnstone, finished<br/>taking evidence in April last year and heard final submissions in<br/>June.<br/></p><p>Mr Johnston today handed down his almost 800-page finding into<br/>the incident to a packed court room in Geelong, where the families<br/>of the dead firefighters sat wearing commemorative red ribbons.<br/></p><p>Mr Johnstone handed down 55 recommendations he said he hoped<br/>would improve the safety for Victoria's professional and volunteer<br/>firefighters. Many changes have already been made to bush<br/>firefighting procedures since the Linton tragedy.<br/></p><p>The full force of the coroner's criticism was levelled at the<br/>poor management of the CFA and Department of Natural Resources and<br/>Environment (DNRE), and the lack of appropriate training for those<br/>sent to dangerous situations.<br/></p><p>He found the CFA and DNRE, Mr Scharf and the owner of a property<br/>neighbouring the forest, Peter Neyland, had contributed to the<br/>deaths.<br/></p><p>But he said Mr Neyland, whose rubbish fire ignited the forest,<br/>"took every reasonable precaution" to put out the fires, while he<br/>did not believe Mr Scharf had the tools or knowledge "to understand<br/>the danger he was in".<br/></p><p>Mr Johnstone reserved his final words for the firemen's<br/>families: "It's obviously been a harrowing experience for each and<br/>every one of you.<br/></p><p>"… I hope that from this comes improvements in safety<br/>systems."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2002</dc:source><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-02-28</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="517"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2002 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:44VP-SVJ0-00VK-21GV-00000-00<published>2002-01-07T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:55Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Domestic News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>NSW: CSIRO research into bushfire systems</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>SYDNEY, Jan 7</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Australian scientists have found a<br/>traditional fire danger meter is seriously inaccurate and may even<br/>put firefighters at risk.<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">Research by CSIRO shows the guidelines attached to the "extreme"<br/>rating on the meter, used in Australia for more than 40 years,<br/>under-predicts rates of fire spread in forests by as much as three<br/>times.<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">The research titled Project Vesta, found firefighters have less<br/>time to get out of the way of an advancing blaze than the meter<br/>estimates.<br/></p><p>"Project Vesta results imply that firefighters have much less<br/>time to retreat from an approaching fire than suggested by<br/>conventional wisdom, particularly after a change in wind<br/>direction," research leader Jim Gould said.<br/></p><p>The familiar meter, on display in all Australian parks with a<br/>black needle pointing to the most appropriate of five colour-coded<br/>ratings of fire danger, is even less accurate when wind speeds are<br/>greater than 15kph.<br/></p><p>The project, which saw more than 100 experimental fires lit in<br/>extreme conditions over a six-year period, has also highlighted<br/>ignorance of the speed at which a forest fire reaches its top<br/>potential spread rate.<br/></p><p>"A fire starting from a line greater than 100 metres long will<br/>burn at its potential rate of spread immediately," Mr Gould said.<br/></p><p>"Before Project Vesta, it was thought that forest fires take<br/>time to reach their full potential spread rate."<br/></p><p>But while an alternative to the Fire Danger Meter will not be<br/>developed until the end of the year, the findings from the project<br/>have been of assistance to NSW firefighters.<br/></p><p>Mr Gould and his CSIRO team took their findings to Rural Fire<br/>Service lectures throughout the year and published many of their<br/>findings in RFS newsletters before the onset of the bushfire<br/>season.<br/></p><p>The new knowledge was incorporated into RFS training and Mr<br/>Gould said the lack of firefighter deaths or serious injuries in<br/>the past fortnight was testament to this.<br/></p><p>"Crews must have taken that information to heart because it's<br/>been an almost injury-free campaign when you consider how many<br/>firefighters are out there," he said.<br/></p><p>"I think agencies have done an excellent job in this regard."<br/></p><p>As well as developing a new national fire prediction system, the<br/>CSIRO team will also research the effect local and regional<br/>landscapes have on bushfires.</p><p>Rural Fire Service Commissioner Phil Koperberg said the service<br/>had known about the meter for some time.<br/></p><p>He said the CSIRO had consulted with the service on an ongoing<br/>basis about the particular model containing significant flaws.<br/></p><p>"Where that's important of course is in terms of firefighter<br/>safety, when one forecast fire will do X and it ends up doing Y.<br/>But this is not new to us and it's not new to any state in the<br/>Commonwealth".<br/></p><p>Mr Koperberg said the fire service had adjusted its practices to<br/>cope with it.<br/></p><p>"… the proof of that lies in the fact that we've just dealt<br/>with 14 horrendous days of fire and we've not had a serious injury<br/>during the entire campaign", he said.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ACT: Bushfires rage through Canberra, close to Government House</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline><author><person><nameText>By Linda McSweeny </nameText></person></author></nitf:byline><nitf:dateline>CANBERRA, Dec 24</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Government House was under threat from<br/>flames, electricity was cut, main roads closed and residents<br/>evacuated when bushfires rapidly spread across Canberra this<br/>afternoon.<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">Authorities were unsure how many fires were burning, with winds<br/>of up to 60kph fanning fires across the capital's fringes, but<br/>those threatening homes had been contained by 2100 AEDT.<br/></p><p nitf:lede="true">Two helicopters from the federal government were deployed to<br/>waterbomb the areas, with fires at one stage within 200 metres of<br/>Government House and the exclusive inner suburb of Red Hill.<br/></p><p>Police directed people to stay indoors and wet down fences and<br/>gutters at the peak of the fire, only announcing most of the fires<br/>were contained well after night fell.<br/></p><p>ACT Emergency Services operations manager David Foot said fire<br/>crews would remain on duty but there was no immediate threat to<br/>households.<br/></p><p>"Due to some tremendous work by the firies out there, the direct<br/>risk to the residents of Curtin, Duffy, Holder areas and O'Connor<br/>has been removed," Mr Foot told ABC radio.<br/></p><p>Residents could have peace of mind that crews would remain on<br/>alert overnight and water bombing would continue, with help from<br/>the Department of Defence, tomorrow, he said.<br/></p><p>"There will be fire units on duty throughout the night," Mr Foot<br/>said.<br/></p><p>NSW fire units were this afternoon called in to aid 36 ACT<br/>brigades battling to contain the fires in Curtin, Holder and Duffy<br/>in the west, O'Connor Ridge and Black Mountain in the north, and<br/>inner-suburban Red Hill.<br/></p><p>Flames from the original Stromlo Forest fire spread rapidly in<br/>mid-afternoon winds, shrouding the city in smoke.<br/></p><p>A house at the Forrest Park Riding School near Yarralumla was<br/>partly damaged and horses were evacuated.<br/></p><p>In the city's north, residents were evacuated and later allowed<br/>to return from a Dryandra Street caravan park near O'Connor Ridge<br/>in Canberra Nature Reserve.<br/></p><p>Electricity was cut to Government House, the National Aquarium<br/>and to houses in Curtin and Yarralumla, later extending to inner<br/>eastern suburbs of Red Hill, Deakin and Forrest.<br/></p><p>Major thoroughfares Adelaide Avenue and Tuggeranong Parkway were<br/>closed, along with other roads including the road to Black Mountain<br/>and to Red Hill, which is home to many diplomats.<br/></p><p>Most remained closed late in the evening.<br/></p><p>The governor-general and his family were safe inside Government<br/>House even though spot fires continued to burn into the night.<br/></p><p>Fire crews were in the grounds and the road into the property<br/>was closed, Dr Hollingworth's personal secretary Martin Bonsey<br/>said.<br/></p><p>"We'll be watching it in confidence that the emergency services<br/>will keep us nice and secure," Mr Bonsey said.<br/></p><p>"And if worst comes to worst, we'll hop in the lake."<br/></p><p>Authorities would not comment about whether the fires were<br/>sparked by arsonists, but said a total fire ban was in place.<br/></p><p>Radio stations broadcast an emergency announcement from ACT<br/>Bushfire Service reassuring people all available crews were on site<br/>to protect the community.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:802H-P9V1-2RYX-12JK-00000-00Black mark over bushfire plan - Blaze overhaul after tragedy2010-08-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:56ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 14Black mark over bushfire plan - Blaze overhaul after tragedyMichelle Draper and Paul Mulvey

VICTIMS of Victoria's horrific Black Saturday bushfires have blasted the final report into the disaster as ``wishy-washy''.

The report from the Royal Commission into the 2009 fires found that the stay-or-go policy was too ``simplistic'' and should be overhauled to include a focus on emergency evacuations during bushfires.

Changes to the controversial policy were among a raft of wide-ranging recommendations included in the long-awaited report, which also suggests appointing a fire commissioner in Victoria to oversee emergencies and promote much-needed reform.

The commissioners made 67 recommendations in their four-volume, 900-page report handed to Victorian Premier John Brumby and tabled in the Victorian parliament yesterday.

Gary Brown, who lost his son, daughter-in-law and three grandchildren in the town of Kinglake, said the report was too vague and gave the Government the room to avoid implementing many of the recommendations.

``To me it's a wishy-washy outcome. It gives them a very easy way of saying `this is all too hard' or `this is going to cost too much money'.''

Mr Brumby acknowledged that systems put in place after previous bushfire disasters in Australia including the 1983 Ash Wednesday fires, failed on Black Saturday.

``All of the steps that were put in place after the Ash Wednesday fires, all of the work of successive governments . . . the reality is that on Black Saturday 2009 those systems failed and 173 lives were lost,'' Mr Brumby said.

The stay-or-go policy was considered to be among the most contentious issues to be raised in the final report, but there was no recommendation to scrap it as anticipated.

Commission chairman Bernard Teague and commissioners Susan Pascoe and Ron McLeod said key elements ``remain sound'' though the stay-or-go policy was too simplistic.

They urged the Government to provide more options for people facing fire danger, including planning for emergency evacuations which would be carried out by police and ordered by incident controllers in charge of fires.

Community fire refuges and bushfire shelters should also be available, with the commissioners criticising the Government for dragging its feet.

One of the biggest changes foreshadowed in the report is the recommendation to appoint a fire commissioner who would become the most senior fire officer in the state.

The fire commissioner's responsibilities would be to spearhead reform and direct chief officers of all fire agencies on extreme fire days.

In other changes, the system of having the emergency services minister ultimately in charge during major bushfires should be dropped and replaced with the state's police chief, the report said. The commissioners said the actions of then police chief Christine Nixon, who left the control centre on the night of the fires, were ``inadequate''.

Police and Emergency Services Minister Bob Cameron acted properly but should have considered advising the Premier to declare a state of disaster, the commissioners said.

Opposition Leader Ted Baillieu committed to implementing all the report's recommendations if the Coalition was elected to government in November.

But Mr Brumby raised questions over whether his party would go that far, saying the Government would consult with the community.

He said the Government would provide a full response ``within weeks''.

2009 VICTORIAN BUSHFIRES ROYAL COMMISSION

THE REPORT

Days since Black Saturday: 540

Number of recommendations: 67

Pages in the final report: 900

Witnesses before commission: 434

Exhibits: 1000

Transcript pages: 20,767

Cost: $40 million

KEY FINDINGS

* The stay-or-go policy is sound but must improve

* A new position of fire commissioner should be created

* Police chief to become 'Co-ordinator-in-chief of Emergency Management.

* People in risk areas should be able to sell their property to the state through a 'retreat and resettlement strategy

* Fuel reduction burns must be doubled

* Warning systems must be enhanced, shelters established and emergency communication networks improved

* Ageing powerlines should be replaced/upgraded

* At-risk regions to have no powerlines within 10 years

* National centre for bushfire research

FACTS:

* It has been estimated the Kinglake-Marysville firestorm north of Melbourne released energy the equivalent of 1500 Hiroshima-sized atom bombs.

* The McArthur Forest Fire Danger Index reached unprecedented levels in the lead-up to Black Saturday, ranging from 120 to more than 200. A figure of 50 was considered extreme.

THE COST:

173 lives lost

500+ people treated for burns

450,000 hectares burned

1200 homes destroyed

60 commercial properties burnt

12 community buildings lost

1000 farm buildings destroyed

11,000+ farm animals killed or injured

Millions of native animals killed or injured

10,000km+ of fencing destroyed

Thousands of tonnes of hay and animal fodder destroyed along with thousands of hectares of fruit trees, plantation timber, pasture and crops

$1.5 billion+ in insurance costs
