urn:contentItem:8034-PHD0-Y9B7-504R-00000-00Highlights of the AAP world wire at 15:00 Aug 22010-08-02T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:56ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSHighlights of the AAP world wire at 15:00 Aug 2PORT VILA Aug 2

  As Prime Minister Julia Gillard stays home to take charge of the election campaign, she's sending her foreign minister to Vanuatu to help sort out issues in the Pacific. (PIF sent at 13:56, 541 words.)


Leaked war files no surprise to Afghans
   KUALA LUMPUR, Aug 2 AFP - Afghan defence minister Abdul Rahim Wardak has played down the fallout from the Wikileaks scandal, saying the information released was "not a big surprise". (AFGHAN LEAKS WARDAK sent at 15:02, 401 words.)
11 killed in China tractor rampage
   BEIJING, Aug 2 AP - A drunken man went on a rampage while driving a shovel loader in northern China, smashing into shops and vehicles and killing 11 people, a government spokesman said on Monday. (CHINA RAMPAGE Update sent at 14:40, 295 words.)
NZ hopes giant ball will inflate tourism
   AUCKLAND, Aug 2 AAP - The wounds are red raw in the land of the wallaby following the All Blacks' near record thumping of Australia at the weekend. (NZ RUGBY (pix available) sent at 13:03, 234 words.)
2 Arizona inmates still at large
   PHOENIX, Aug 2 AP - The search for two convicted murderers who escaped from a private prison in northwest Arizona continued on Sunday, while a third escaped convict was back behind bars following an early-morning shootout with police in western Colorado. (US ESCAPEES sent at 14:18, 369 words.)
ADB projects modest growth for Pacific
   MANILA, Philippines, Aug 2 AP - The economies of the Pacific region, led by resource-rich East Timor, are projected to expand 4.3 per cent this year but inflation remains a concern, driven by high fuel and utility prices, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) said on Monday. (PHIL ADB sent at 13:19, 332 words.)
BP boss 'absolutely' would eat Gulf fish
   NEW ORLEANS, Louisiana, Aug 1 AFP - BP's chief operating officer sought to give the southern US fishing industry a much-need boost on Sunday, saying he'd "absolutely" eat Gulf of Mexico seafood after the massive oil spill devastated the region. (US RIG BP sent at 09:48, 347 words.)
Firefighting plane crash kills 2
   VICTORIA, British Columbia, Aug 2 AP - Two pilots were confirmed dead on Sunday in the crash of a Canadian waterbombing plane that was fighting a forest fire. (CANADA FIRES PLANE sent at 11:26, 359 words.)
Hundreds of new wildfires break out
   VORONEZH, Russia, Aug 2 AP - Hundreds of new fires have broken out in Russian forests and fields that have been dried to a crisp by drought and record heat, but firefighters claimed success in bringing some of the wildfires raging around cities under control. (RUSSIA HEATWAVE sent at 10:35, 518 words.)
Cold cuts could cause cancer: study
   WASHINGTON, Aug 2 AFP - Red meat is being raked over the coals again. Already linked with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease and certain cancers, including cancer of the pancreas, red meat was found by a team of US researchers to be a possible cause of bladder cancer, a study published in the journal Cancer said. (MED MEAT sent at 14:58, 352 words.)
Improvements at Michigan oil spill site
   LANSING, Michigan, Aug 2 AP - A regional administrator for the Environmental Protection Agency said on Sunday that significant improvement had been made at the site of an oil spill in a southern Michigan river, but the agency cautioned that it will take months to complete the cleanup. (US SPILL sent at 11:50, 392 words.)
Moat to be buried on Monday
   LONDON, Aug 2 PA - The funeral of gunman Raoul Moat will take place on Monday. (UK SHOOTING sent at 12:04, 228 words.)
Trash threatens to jam Three Gorges dam
   BEIJING, Aug 2 AFP - Layers of rubbish floating in the Yangtze river are threatening to jam China's massive Three Gorges hydroelectric dam, state media reported on Monday. (CHINA RUBBISH sent at 14:45, 314 words.)
Soldiers search N.Korea border area
   SEOUL, Aug 2 AFP - Hundreds of South Korean soldiers searched the border area with North Korea on Monday for unexploded landmines after a blast killed one man and wounded another, military officials said. (KOREA MINES sent at 14:51, 298 words.)
North sank boat over aid: report
   SEOUL, Aug 2 AFP - North Korea attacked a South Korean warship after the South baulked at its request for economic aid in return for a proposed summit, a report said on Monday. (KOREA SHIP sent at 14:29, 291 words.)
Chechen Islamist Umarov to step down
   MOSCOW, Aug 2 AFP - Chechnya's guerrilla chief and self-proclaimed "Emir of the Caucasus" Doku Umarov announced on Sunday he was stepping down in a video posted on YouTube. (RUSSIA CHECHNYA sent at 12:23, 423 words.)

urn:contentItem:7VNF-S171-2RG6-Y01X-00000-00CFA denies fire warnings came too late2009-05-11T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisPM6:18 PM AESTABCSamantha DonovanCFA denies fire warnings came too late

MARK COLVIN: The chief officer of Victoria's Country Fire Authority (CFA) has faced a long day of questioning on the first day of hearings of the Bushfire Royal Commission.

Russell Rees has defended the adequacy of warnings given to communities on Black Saturday.

But he's been quizzed on a number of aspects of the CFA's response, including the effectiveness of communication throughout the organisation.

Samantha Donovan reports.

SAMANTHA DONOVAN: The adequacy of warnings to the public during February's bushfires is one of the biggest issues for the Royal Commission to assess.

Today, the chief officer of Victoria's Country Fire Authority, Russell Rees, faced a long day of questioning on how the authority hierarchy responded to the threat on Black Saturday.

He defended the timing of the CFA's warnings to the public.

RUSSELL REES: The official warnings clearly were very, very close in terms of to the actual events; in other words the time frames are very, very tight in the getting of information and the issuing of warnings.

SAMANTHA DONOVAN: Satellite maps plotting the course of several of the February fires were used at the commission today.

Thirty-eight people were killed in Kinglake by the Kilmore East fire.

Counsel assisting the commission Jack Rush QC suggested to Russell Rees that maps had been prepared showing the likely progress of the fire hours before the community was warned.

JACK RUSH: As a layman Mr Rees, and I look at that map at 1600, why wouldn't a warning be given to Kinglake at 1600?

RUSSELL REES: The warning was given, as I suspect you know, at around 1755 for Kinglake. That's the urgent threat official warning.

Every effort was made and hindsight is a wonderful thing, as we all know, but people were making efforts to warn the communities, including the community of Kinglake and in realising the whole state and the issues that pertained to the risks to the whole state at the time.

SAMANTHA DONOVAN: Jack Rush QC observed that the Country Fire Authority has the statutory responsibility for declaring days of total fire ban.

But as Russell Rees told the commission, that responsibility doesn't extend to the issuing of warnings.

RUSSELL REES: CFA seeks to give information but it depends on the public understanding of that information and taking that information in.

JACK RUSH: Does the CFA warn or does it provide information?

RUSSELL REES: The CFA's policy is that it gives advice to the community before and during fires. If one wants to interpret that advice as a warning, I don't shy away from the language warning, but there is much more in what CFA is striving to do than simply to warn.

SAMANTHA DONOVAN: In the wake of the fires, many residents of affected towns have asked why sirens weren't sounded to alert them of the approaching fires.

But chief officer Russell Rees says sirens at CFA stations aren't used for that purpose.

RUSSELL REES: Importantly, the use of the CFA siren at a fire station is not for the purpose of warning the public. The use of the siren on a CFA fire station is for alerting fire brigade members to respond to fire.

SAMANTHA DONOVAN: Although he isn't ruling out the use of sirens in future.

RUSSELL REES: Nothing is off the agenda in this discussion. There are however severe limitations in audible warnings.

SAMANTHA DONOVAN: What's known as the Forest Fire Danger Index was almost off the charts on Black Saturday, with an almost unprecedented reading of 328.

Russell Rees was asked why that figure wasn't communicated to the public.

RUSSELL REES: To understand those figures, as in the numerical numbers of the fire danger indices, you need to understand what they mean; so there needs to be an educative process. And the language of low, moderate to extreme, high extreme, is the language that's considered best to explain that scenario.

SAMANTHA DONOVAN: The CFA's Russell Rees was excused from the witness box late this afternoon but it's expected he'll be called to give evidence several times during the commission's hearings.

His counterpart at the Victorian Department of Sustainability and Environment Ewan Waller was the next witness called this afternoon and he'll resume his testimony tomorrow morning.

MARK COLVIN: Samantha Donovan.

urn:contentItem:4P6W-51J0-TXN5-R2VH-00000-00Gathering of the Penguins2005-12-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisSPECTRUMPg. 22Gathering of the PenguinsCOLLECTIONSEdward Wyatt, The New York Times

When a forest fire forced Kathryn Gursky to evacuate her Los Alamos home in May 2000, she took with her just one book, a British edition of The World of Pooh, by A.A. Milne, bought when she and her husband were on holiday in Dorset 11 years earlier.

When she returned after the fire, Gursky, a 49-year-old former librarian, found that the rest of her 2300-volume personal library had burned, along with her house and everything in it.

Thousands of scorched tree trunks still range up the hillside across the street from Gursky's new home, but her library is well on the way to recovery. In September, she received a birthday gift from her husband that earned her the envy of her book-loving friends: the complete Penguin Classics Library, 1082 books sold only by Amazon.com for nearly $US8000 ($10,900).

Penguin Classics, the paperback volumes with the familiar black spine and the orange-and-black penguin logo, are known to generations of former students who struggled through Dickens and dozed through Henry James in school.

Not since Penguin started the collection in 1946, however, has anyone been able to easily buy a complete set of the books, which range from ancient Greek poetry to the novels of Thomas Pynchon and include the complete works of Shakespeare, four translations of the Iliad and 20 volumes each of the works of Henry James and Dickens. (The complete list can be found at www.amazon.com by searching for "Penguin Classics Library".)

"We'd always wanted to sell them together, but it was always an issue of how could we sell all of the books in a single bookstore," says Tim McCall, Penguin's director of online sales and marketing, noting that most bookstores carry only a few hundred titles in the series. "Finally, the internet became mature enough to give us the ability to display all the books and to reach an audience out there that might want them."

Gursky's collection arrived in mid-September packed in 25 boxes, shrink-wrapped on a pallet and weighing almost 320 kilograms. She has spent countless hours unpacking, shelving, categorising, alphabetising and rearranging the books. Oh, yes - and reading; she has read more than 30 of the books in eight weeks. Even at that rather remarkable pace, it would take her about six years to make her way through the entire collection.

So where did she start? "I ran my finger along the shelves, closed my eyes and stopped on one," Gursky said, sitting in her new library, 31 rows of great literature looming behind her.

She picked Herland, a feminist utopian novel by Charlotte Perkins Gilman, combined in one Penguin volume with Gilman's short fiction and poetry.

Despite its daunting scope, the Penguin Classics Library Complete Collection is not actually complete. Penguin lists about 1300 titles in its catalogue but included only 1082 in the Amazon collection. "We included every title in stock at sufficient levels to ensure the continued availability of the collection," McCall says. "In the final analysis, there were approximately 200 titles that did not make the cut due to limited availability, most often because they were on our schedule to be completely revised."

Amazon will not say how many sets have been sold so far or who has bought them, citing the need to protect buyers' privacy. Penguin seems not to know who the buyers are, other than Gursky, who acknowledged her ownership in a review of the collection on Amazon's website.

urn:contentItem:48P6-9H10-015H-G00Y-00000-00<published>2003-05-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:53:55Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 2</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Start your day with a laugh</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">*  A MAN walking down the street noticed a boy trying to reach the doorbell of a house.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Even when he jumped up, he couldn't quite reach it. The man decided to help the boy, so walked on to the porch and pushed the bell.</p><p>He smiled at the boy and asked: "What now?"</p><p>The boy answered: "Now we run like crazy!"</p><p> *  A PHOTOGRAPHER for a national magazine was assigned to get photos of a great forest fire.</p><p>Smoke at the scene was too thick to get good shots, so he called his office to hire a plane.</p><p>"It will be waiting for you at the airport!" he was assured by his editor.</p><p>As soon as he got to the small, rural airport, a plane was warming up near the runway.</p><p>He jumped in with his equipment and yelled: "Let's go! Let's go!"</p><p>The pilot swung the plane into the wind and soon they were in the air.</p><p>"Fly over the north side of the fire," said the photographer, "and make three or four low-level passes." "Why?" asked the pilot.</p><p>"Because I'm going to take pictures. I'm a photographer, and photographers take pictures," the photographer said.</p><p>After a long pause the pilot said: "You mean you're not the instructor?"</p><p> *  A FARM boy accidentally overturned his wagonload of corn.</p><p>The farmer who lived nearby heard the noise and yelled over to the boy: "Hey Willis, forget your troubles. Come in and visit with us. I'll help you get the wagon up later."</p><p>"That's mighty nice of you," Willis answered, "but I don't think Pa would like me to."</p><p>"Oh, come on boy," the farmer insisted.</p><p>"Well okay," the boy finally agreed, and added, "but Pa won't like it."</p><p>After dinner, Willis thanked his host. "I feel a lot better, but I know Pa is going to be upset."</p><p>"Don't be foolish," the neighbour said. "By the way, where is he?"</p><p>"Under the wagon!'</p><p> *  A MAN selling carpet called a home and a little boy with a whisper answered the phone.</p><p>The man introduced himself to the child and asked if he could speak to his father. The little boy said no so the man asked why not? The little boy exclaimed: "He's busy."</p><p>So the man asked to speak with his mother, the little boy said no so the man asked why not? The little boy said: "She's busy."</p><p>The man asked if there were any other grown-ups in the house. The little boy said there was a policeman and fireman.</p><p>The man asked to speak to the policeman and the little boy said: "He's busy."</p><p>So the man asked to speak to the fireman. "No, he's busy."</p><p>Puzzled, the man said: "There are four grown-ups in your house and they are all busy, do you mind if I ask what are they doing?"</p><p>The little boy, still whispering, says: "Yeah, they're looking for me."</p><p> *  A WOMAN lost her purse at the shop but an honest teenage boy returned it to her.</p><p>The woman looked inside her purse and said: "That's strange, earlier I had a $20 note inside, but now it's gone, and instead I see two fives and a ten."</p><p>"That's right," the boy explained, "the last time I found a lady's purse, she didn't have change for a reward."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:7V8C-10C0-YB64-41YB-00000-00Blackout for Earth on March 282009-03-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:56ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESLeadersPg. 12Blackout for Earth on March 28

EARTH HOUR, the movement which began in one city - Sydney - just two years ago has spread like wildfire. We use the simile deliberately. The past 12 months have been a year of fire. Australians, scarred in recent days by one of the worst ever bushfire seasons, know well the destructive power of fire, quite apart from the human tragedy. They have first-hand knowledge from the fires of Black Saturday that these disasters are getting worse in a landscape already blasted by drought. They know, too, the warming of Earth's climate will make such severe events more frequent and more destructive.

They are of course not alone. Fires in California burned hundreds of homes and tens of thousands of hectares last November. Parts of Lebanon burned in October. Before that, on Rhodes, a large fire offered a reminder of the previous year's horrific fires through Greece. Earlier this month, a NASA satellite took pictures of a rare large-scale forest fire in Nepal, in the foothills of the frozen Himalayas. The Earth is getting burned by global warming.

Not only are fires the result of worsening drought caused by global warming, but they hasten that warming by releasing vast amounts of carbon into the atmosphere. That will no doubt be part of the reason why Earth's carbon sinks - the oceans and forests which in the past have soaked up a little more than half the carbon dioxide produced by human activity - are becoming less effective, according to recent research cited in Climate Change In Australia, jointly produced by the CSIRO and the Bureau of Meteorology.

The news was bad two years ago when Earth Hour started. It is worse now. Carbon dioxide emissions are increasing faster than the worst-case scenario imagined by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change in 2007.

Fire is a tangible thing, an obvious sign of the change that is happening. Beyond the immediate reaction of fear and grief at its destruction, and the outpouring of generosity to help its victims, there is a growing unease at the thought that Earth's fiery present might be just a foretaste of the future. What will the climate be like if nothing is done? More fires will burn, certainly. There are plenty of other effects, though: storms and hurricanes increasing in frequency and intensity; melting glaciers and icecaps; rising sea levels; dwindling water supplies; dying rivers; spreading deserts. That unease at what the future may hold is heightened when politicians bicker over what is to be done and quail before the seriousness of the threat, economists dither over what mechanism might best harness the market to reverse present trends, and investors and industrialists do their best to stymie any change at all.

But if the dangers from global warming have grown as the climate heats under its greenhouse of man-made gas emissions, so too has a determination to face the problem squarely and to beat it.

In 2007 one city in one country was involved: our city, Sydney. The Herald backed the World Wildlife Fund's campaign to highlight concern for the fate of the Earth by encouraging readers to switch off lights and power for one hour. The response was overwhelming: 2.2 million homes and businesses blacked out to show their support.

The next year, the event went to all Australian capitals and overseas. In 11 countries, 26 cities signed up and 50 million people took action.

This year the event has gone global. The organisers thought they would get 1000 towns and cities to join; they have now signed up nearly twice that number, in 81 countries.

This year the event has been shaped as a vote for the Earth. Certainly the planet needs your support. As our politicians head for Copenhagen, to devise the climate treaty that will shape the world's response to this vast, intractable threat, they need to be made aware that behind them, in all the countries they come from, there is a reservoir at least as vast of public support - not for temporising or delay, nor for protecting special interests - but for effective action to address the problem.

Earth Hour is the way to have your say. Next Saturday night, March 28, between 8.30 and 9.30, switch off to cast your vote.

urn:contentItem:7V0G-BGX0-YBDY-R02H-00000-00Water rained from heaven2009-02-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Water rained from heavenGeorgie Pilcher

"I didn't want to stand up, my hair was on fire then I realised the connector hose and I tried to put it out with my finger.

I was hanging on to a gas bottle. Ash was falling on Then someone threw me a blanket"

Amelia Coombes

AS her hair caught fire Amelia Coombes looked up and into the eyes of CFA legend Barry Mapley.

Trapped in a ring of fire and hanging on to a gas tank, the 24-year-old sheltered in the back of the ute with her three dogs as her boyfriend Paul Mercieca, 33, drove around in circles. Both believed they were destined to perish.

``I didn't want to stand up, my hair was on fire. Then I realised I was hanging on to a gas bottle,'' she recalled yesterday.

``Ash was falling on the connector hose and I tried to put it out with my finger. Then someone threw me a blanket."

From over the burning hill came the CFA from Eurobin.

Inside the Eurobin truck was Mr Mapley, Mark Bursill, Shaun Raoss and Malcolm McKinnon.

As fire roared above and below the couple, the fire crew put their God-sent truck into the firing line and sprayed them with heavenly water, saving their lives.

With their Mudgegonga valley house already burning and gas bottles from Mr Mercieca's welding shed exploding one by one, the couple thought their time had come.

After 32 years as the Eurobin CFA captain Mr Mapley, 67, knew they were in deadly peril.

Mr Mercieca recalled how he ``bloody didn't want to be there . . . that fire was unstoppable".

``A gas bottle took the roof off the house and then there was another big one (explosion). My son-in-law said 'get out of here we are going to die'.

``Then I seen this truck he (Mr Mapley) was driving. She was sitting in the back with dogs. We screamed 'don't leave, don't leave'."

Seeing salvation, Mr Mercieca drove alongside the Eurobin truck.

``I didn't want to be there but we couldn't move because we would have left them," Mr Mapley recalled.

``So we shielded them and we hung it out too. The fire went under us and over them.

``Yep it was howling. It was sparking and coming over the top of them. They wouldn't have survived."

Still running on adrenaline since the murderous Mudegonga fire ripped through the valley at 1.30am on Sunday, the trio

broke down as they were reunited yesterday.

Mr Mercieca, who is the cousin of Melbourne underworld wife Roberta Williams, shed tears as he slapped his hero on the back.

``I've never seen anything move like that. She was pretty close there mate," he said.

``I'm not a bloody hero. It's just the Aussie way," Mr Mapley replied.

``I didn't know what to do. Would I have been better to try and put it out with the hose?" Mr Mercieca asked his hero.

``Nup, you'd be toast," was the factual reply.

Down the road yesterday another Mudgegonga couple were trying to find the policeman who saved their lives. They had decided to stay and fight, but the policeman convinced them to flee.

``He came to take names of the people who were staying. It was the tone of his voice when he said: 'You should go and you should go now'," Karen Ward, 54, said.

``If we had done what they tell you and stayed inside and wait for the fire to pass we would have exploded."

The couple fled in two cars to the top of a nearby hill where they watched their house burn.

``That copper saved our lives. He is the bravest man I've ever met."

With husband Dwayne, Mrs Ward yesterday returned to find her pet goat was still alive but nothing of her house remaining.

``This was our tinnie boat,'' she said as she held two tangled pieces of metal."

As she spoke, a convoy of trucks carrying donated hay to feed dying stock passed on the

highway.

``Now that's a pretty sight," she said.

Locals in Mudgegonga and the Beechworth valleys yesterday marked day one of their long battle to recovery.

With hundreds of crews working to control the still burning forest fire near Running Creek those who lost everything declared battle on mother nature.

Power was beginning to

be restored and phone lines

connected.

But no matter how hard it gets they know they are some of the lucky ones.

urn:contentItem:4P0N-JXF0-TXN5-S2WK-00000-00Conditions worse in the mountains2003-01-21T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Conditions worse in the mountainsTHE FIRES · VICTORIAAndra Jackson, Jamie Berry with AAP

Fires in Victoria's north-east have claimed more than 100,000 hectares of bushland ahead of another predicted tough day for firefighters today.

High temperatures and strong winds caused erratic fire conditions yesterday and extreme weather conditions are predicted for the north-east today.

The Country Fire Authority has declared a total fire ban in the north-east. Firefighters have warned that a potentially dangerous wind change is due.

The three main Victorian fires are at Pinnabar in the Upper Murray south of Corryong, Mount Buffalo and the Bogong region.

Department of Sustainability and Environment chief fire officer Gary Morgan said the wind change about noon would bring the greatest danger. "Tomorrow brings us a heightened degree of fire risk across the state," he said yesterday.

As a fire at Mount Beauty spread to 7000 hectares, it linked up with fires at Mount Bogong, Mount Feathertop, Mountain Creek, Bald Hill and Razorback. The Mount Beauty fire destroyed a holiday home north of Benambra.

The merged Bogong complex of fires had claimed 62,000 hectares and was the one that had firefighters most worried.

With the fire still six kilometres from the Mount Beauty township, residents were told to decide whether to stay or go, Department of Sustainability and Environment spokeswoman Marcia Johns said.

"Most people were preparing to stay," she said.

Ms Johns said the fires, now in their third week, had razed about 60,000 hectares in the north-east since the weekend. Now they had almost doubled in size. "These fires are really too big to try and directly attack," said Ms Johns. "We are hoping to keep people safe and to protect their assets."

In the Nariel Valley, near Benambra, more than 20 properties were placed under threat and residents were urged to evacuate or implement bushfire action plans at two properties.

The Mount Buffalo fire is expected to breach containment lines as weather conditions deteriorate.

The Pinnabar fire has destroyed a communications tower and burnt through more than 20,000 hectares of bushland. It had linked with blazes across the state border into the Kosciuszko National Park.

Heavy smoke caused problems getting fire aircraft in the air during the day.

Thirteen New Zealand firefighters with specialist forest fire knowledge helped relieve fire crews yesterday and 100 army reservists arrived in Myrtleford yesterday to help build firebreaks before backburning.

Firefighters took more than three-and-a-half hours to control a grassfire that burnt about 15 hectares of grassland just north of Glenrowan about 4pm yesterday.

The heritage-protected Red Robin gold mine has been burnt by the Mount Feathertop fire. The mine had been operating since 1939.

Smoke from the bushfires, combined with those in Canberra and NSW, caused a thick haze over Melbourne and other parts of Victoria, with the EPA reporting poor air quality across the state.

The haze forced Qantas to divert two Melbourne-bound international flights to Sydney.

Smoke also caused several call-outs for respiratory problems across the city.

Premier Steve Bracks has cut short his holiday to talk to firefighters returning from the fire front in Myrtleford this morning. -- with AAP

urn:contentItem:7V15-8XF0-YBDY-R01P-00000-00Time to tackle burning issue2009-02-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisPg. 19Time to tackle burning issueBRUCE FELMINGHAM

DAVID Packham, former supervising meteorologist at the Victorian Bureau of Meteorology, unceremoniously dumped the blame for Victoria's firestorm holocaust on those green activists who consistently oppose controlled burns as an integral part of forestry management practice (The Australian, February 12).

He argues there are members of the green movement who are behaving like eco-terrorists waging a jihad against the proponents of controlled burns.

This argument was backed up by scenes surrounding a house which survived the holocaust because the land surrounding had been cleared. The local Green-dominated council had sued the owners for breaking the council's changed planning laws about removing trees.

The cost of legal action had ruined the family financially but at least their actions saved their home.

On balance this criticism of the green activists is excessive because we know now that there are many other factors which explain the causes and intensity of Victoria's Black Saturday.

The royal commission appointed by the Victorian government should reveal all these factors.

Many Tasmanians have first-hand experience of the intensity of a fire storm having lived through Black Tuesday on February 7, 1967, when 73 Tasmanians perished and 1100 homes were destroyed.

More recently, a bushfire on Tasmania's East Coast swept through Scamander and its environs -- its intensity again fuelled by a dense, dry uncleared undergrowth.

Australian Greens Senator Bob Brown has responded to this criticism by arguing that the greens are not opposed to regeneration burns generally, and they do support the ecologically appropriate use of fire, whatever ``ecologically appropriate'' means.

Dr Brown and the Tasmanian Greens do not show the same flexibility in dealing with Forestry Tasmania's regeneration burns, which they appear to see as unnecessary, creating visual pollution impacting on tourism and the health of locals.

Their argument about forest-fire management seems to run as follows ``if fire is kept out of Australia's forests the trees will grow, canopies will close up, the ground will moisten and there will be fewer wildfires.''

I could not find a skerrick of scientific evidence to support this argument but I can find plenty in relation to the benefits of controlled burning, which removes most of the dry undercover, reduces the probability of wildfire and makes the suppression of fire easier.

Clive Hamilton, of Australia Foundation fame, blames Victoria's fire holocaust on global warming. I think this is a furphy.

If Black Saturday is the result of global warming then what about the other bushfire travesties which seem to occur each January-February somewhere in Australia?

Victoria alone has experienced galeforce wind-driven fires in 40 degree plus heat in 1919, 1926, 1932, 1939 and 1994 with the same tragic outcomes.

January 13, 1939, was previously the big daddy of all fires, accounting for 70 lives, two million hectares burnt and 1300 homes lost.

These varied accounts about the causes of bushfires are confused, confusing and dangerous because if we do not understand the causes of fire then we will never know what to do when fire confronts us.

Confusion also extends to the advice offered by the relevant authorities.

When fire sweeps through do we stay with the family home or abandon it and when do we abandon it?

The answer seems to vary from state to state, presumably because fire conditions vary so we are not sure about the answers to such critical issues.

Australia, and Tasmania in particular, has a myriad of planning schemes and laws and it is important that the planning laws have a degree of uniformity.

The question about our capacity to take a national rather than local approach to fire control and management must be high on the list of the terms of reference for the royal commission.

Social capital, the level of trust and reciprocity existing in society, gives rise to the sense of community on which social cohesion is based.

We have managed over the years to run down our stock of social capital, an outcome which is largely explained by the electronic revolution.

It has tended to isolate us in our living rooms, degrading our sense of community.

It is sad that we must wait for catastrophes such as Black Friday to rebuild our stock of social capital but that's exactly what has happened. There has never been a better time to love your neighbour.

* Dr Bruce Felmingham is a leading commentator on economics and business.

urn:contentItem:52GP-H331-F0JP-W1S8-00000-00Fickle weather dampens debate2011-03-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:53:55ZLexisNexisLETTERSPg. 26Fickle weather dampens debate

JUST imagine how the global-warming alarmists would be carrying on if our top temperature was 34.2C on Sunday as it was on the same date in 1884.

I can imagine my great-grandparents shrugging and accepting that weather is fickle.

The fighting and tensions over global warming seem so ridiculous when we all know that one eruption from a volcano, or one massive forest fire would undo years of our efforts to help nature -- a law unto itself.

We should decide to just look after, and enjoy, what we have.

Marion Downes

Grovedale

Girls have always been upstaged

FOR as long as I can remember, there has always been little girls learning to dance.

There were always concerts where they were made up to perform not once but several times a year.

There was rivalry between the girls and also the mothers.

The only difference I can see here is that the media was not involved.

Dianne Senn,

Avondale Heights

Monarchy is not meaningless

IN Saturday's Herald Sun, there was a reader's nasty comment on the royal family -- about wasting money on a ``a couple of old poms'' -- and a letter on ``a meaningless monarchy''.

Do these people stop to think? First, on the huge amounts of taxpayers' money on such things as the visit of Oprah Winfrey or the Grand Prix. Secondly -- and vastly more important to any thinking person -- on the dreadful turmoil, sorrow and destruction of Libya and other war-torn republics.

Our system of government may not suit everybody, but we should all be grateful for the peace and stability of our country and acknowledge that Queen Elizabeth has never intruded on our way of life, but has been a symbol of justice.

R.R, Pascoe Vale

Stop whining about refugees

AUSTRALIA does not need a referendum on asylum-seekers because referenda are only about changing provisions of the constitution.

The refugee convention, co-written by Australia, was ratified on April 22, 1954, and is a legally binding humanitarian treaty. It's got nothing to do with border security or people-smuggling or locking people up on mounds of birds . . . and shooting at them.

The fact is we only have 0.001 per cent of the world's refugees but whine more than any other country on Earth.

Marilyn Shepherd, Angaston

Saints turn rules into rugby

DOES the AFL Commission have the power to suspend the St Kilda Football Club coaching staff for bringing the game into disrepute?

Their game plan consists of the whole team following the ball and developing into a rugby maul.

I feel sorry for their gifted footballers who do not have a chance to showcase their skills.

The later that Channel Seven can delay telecasts of St Kilda games the better. Can I suggest after midnight?

I see the Saints are playing the Richmond midgets next Friday night, so they will at least be able to practise a long-kicking, high-marking game.

Graham Griffiths, Montmorency

Soldiers trained to hate enemy

I SERVED my country for 11 years and am happy to say so, but this rubbish about racism has got to be put into context.

I joined the infantry and can tell you we were trained to be racist. Back in '92, we were taught to hate.

How do you think you can pull the trigger on another person? You have to think of the enemy, civilian or soldier, as scum. You have to be ready to kill instinctively.

How do you think the Defence Force achieves that? They make you angry or stressed to a point that if you are ambushed, a soldier's button is pushed and you run firing your weapon straight toward the danger.

In recruit training, the instructors even made us watch Romper Stomper at least 10 times to instil hate for other races. You have to be full of enough hate that you can drive a bayonet into somebody and look into their eyes as they die.

This fuss about soldiers in Afghanistan calling the people who they see names is just stress relief and probably pointing out to each other possible dangers, like suicide bombers.

Stretto, ex-army

LETTER OF THE DAY

WELL, well, mothers living their own failed dream of being a beauty queen (Little Beauties on Show, 26/3).

In my opinion, the role of a mother is doing what is right for the child.

Plucking out eyebrows has a touch of senseless vanity, and is not in the child's best interest.

The young girls in this competition will believe that beauty is everything, which is not a real confidence-booster.

Do mothers ever stop to think how their child will feel if she loses? And most of them must lose.

Self-esteem and confidence begin in a person's mind when they accept themselves, and do their best with their God-given talent, whether it is in sport or the creative arts.

Ideals for young girls should not be about how beautiful one can look, but how beautiful one is inside.

The truly beautiful child is one who is kind, patient, respectful and friendly to other children.

See these pageants for what they are: money-making tools.

Eliatha Pallaris, Donvale
